Photos by Rub√©n Salgado Escudero (@rubensalgadoescudero) | Being on assignment in Costa Rica gave me a glimpse into the Ticos‚Äô approach to life‚ÄîPura Vida. More than just a saying, it‚Äôs a way of connecting with others, of not letting life‚Äôs challenges weigh more than they should, and of honoring the incredible natural richness this country has to offer.  1. I came across these two White-Faced Capuchins grooming each other‚Äîtheir striking white face makes them one of Costa Rica‚Äôs most recognizable monkeys. The one being groomed looked directly at me in a trance-like state of relaxation. This is their way of establishing connection with each other and reducing stress, not so different from us. I often saw these playful creatures leaping through the trees, surrounded by the sounds and movement of countless other species that call this forest home.  2. I‚Äôd never been much of a coffee drinker, but I left Costa Rica with a newfound appreciation for what is a favorite daily ritual for many. When I met Manuel, the 4th generation farmer on the family-run coffee plantation, Aquiares, he spoke passionately about what coffee means to his community‚Äîthe love, dedication, and precision that go into every step of its production. In Costa Rica, coffee is clearly much more than a drink; it‚Äôs a ritual to be savored as fully as life itself. Pura Vida!  3. I watched this Yellow-throated Toucan‚Äîalso known as the Chestnut-mandibled Toucan, the largest in Costa Rica‚Äîfeast on fruit from a palm tree at the Osa Conservation Center. The incredible diversity of wildlife here truly blew me away. Everywhere I turned, there seemed to be a new species moving through this lush, living paradise. | Pura vida awaits. üåø Explore lush rainforests, majestic volcanoes, and sun-kissed beaches. Photo by @jessicasample | Quaking aspens are among North America's most common deciduous trees, turning vibrant yellow in the fall. Here they're seen reflected in Jenny Lake in Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming.  Each tree in an aspen grove is connected to a single root system, allowing new trunks to grow from underground roots. This means many trees share the same genetics. While trunks can live up to a century, the root systems may be hundreds or thousands of years old.

From the air, they look like shards of glass scattered across the Atlantic. From the water, they rise like cathedrals, icebergs drifting past Newfoundland and Labrador after breaking free from Greenland‚Äôs glaciers.  Only about 10 percent of an iceberg is visible above the surface, the rest is hidden beneath the waves. Some of these giants are more than 10,000 years old, formed from snow that fell before the Pyramids were built. Each one carries ancient air bubbles from a vanished climate, and enough fresh water to sustain a city for months.  To see them from both a helicopter and a boat is to witness two worlds at once, the immensity of Earth‚Äôs frozen past and the fragile present, which is melting faster than ever.  Learn more about Nat Geo photographer Ami Vitale‚Äôs (@amivitale) time in Canada‚Äôs Atlantic Islands and the communities that call them home at the link in bio. | In @ExploreCanada, once in a lifetime happens more often than you think.

Video by @filipe_deandrade | There‚Äôs no mistaking it, the Pantanal is full of character. From the revered jaguars that hunt its shadows to the Pantaneiros who ride through its grasslands, this place doesn‚Äôt just look wild, it feels wild. It‚Äôs textured, layered, and competing to be alive.  You hear it in the morning chorus of hyacinth macaws, in the distant calls of howler monkeys, and in the rhythmic hammering of hooves as they cross wooden bridges. You smell it in the woodsmoke from open-air kitchens and even on yourself. It‚Äôs a symphony of the senses, one that demands your attention in every moment.  And as a photographer? It‚Äôs a dream. Golden light lasts longer, colors seem bolder, and the wildlife flows naturally into every frame. But even more than that, the Pantanal feels honest. What you see is what you get, and what you get is untamable Brazil.  As someone who lives to tell stories with a camera, I felt completely at home here. The sounds, the people, the jaguars. It‚Äôs nature, untamed. And I wouldn‚Äôt have it any other way. | The Pantanal: Jaguar sightings, stunning wetlands, and rich Pantaneiro traditions‚ÄîBrazil‚Äôs Pantanal is calling. Photo and video by @michaelgeorge | The Oiran Parade is a reenactment of the elaborate processions once held by high-ranking courtesans (oiran) in Japan‚Äôs Edo period.   Masters of calligraphy, music, dance, and other arts, oiran were esteemed not only for their skills but also as fashion icons. During the parade, the oiran glide forward in complicated kimono layers, their hair styled in intricate ornaments, all while performing the hachi-monji no ashi‚Äîthe signature figure-eight walking style‚Äîatop towering koma-geta (platform sandals).   Edo Wonderland, located in Nikko, Japan, was first described to me as a ninja theme park. While that‚Äôs not entirely wrong (a ninja did jump out at me upon my arrival), the park is also a fully immersive historical experience, with shrines, Edo-era streets, and theater performances that transport you back in time.   Rather than romanticizing the Edo period, the parade honors the artistry of the oiran and sheds light on an important yet often misunderstood chapter of Japan‚Äôs history.   To learn more, follow my travels @michaelgeorge.

For more than a century, safaris have been shaped by outsiders.  The safari industry began in the late 19th century, during the colonial era, when European explorers and American adventurers traveled to the interiors of East and Southern Africa for cartography and game hunting. To this day, many safari lodges and camps are primarily owned by white male individuals, mainly serving white, affluent international travelers.   A small but growing group of African entrepreneurs is working to change that‚Äîredefining who benefits from Africa‚Äôs wildlife and reshaping the future of safaris.  Learn more about how these trailblazers are pushing for change in the billion-dollar safari industry at the link in bio.   Photograph by Kleinjan Groenewald via Batoka Africa and Zambezi Sands Lodge Production and Styling by Happy Go Lucky

Photo by Linh Pham @phamhaduylinh | Nestled in the northwestern corner of Vietnam, the Hoang Lien Son range (seen here from Mount Fansipan), an eastern extension of the Himalaya, is not only the backbone of the country‚Äôs topography but also a haven for diverse wildlife and ethnic minorities like the Hmong, Xa Pho, Tay, and Dao. Towering over the region is Fansipan, Vietnam‚Äôs highest peak at 3,147 meters (10,325 ft), offering breathtaking views and accessible via cable car or a challenging multiday trek. The lush slopes of this range, located within Hoang Lien Son National Park, host more than 2,000 plant species and a variety of fauna.

My first day in the Southern Pantanal, I thought I had stepped out of reality and into nature‚Äôs coloring book. Vivacious skies, rainbow-themed birds, and a massive cast of wildlife characters. ‚ÄúThis is a photographer‚Äôs dream‚Äù was the thought that played on repeat. The trumpet trees had just come into bloom, so everywhere I looked, there was a unique image waiting to be made.  As striking as the landscape and its complementary characters were, it was the jaguar that remained my main attraction. And my first sighting couldn‚Äôt have been more memorable. A beautiful female and her cub rewarded my patience with an entire morning of intimate behavior. Grooming, playing, resting in the open shade just meters from our Oncafari vehicle. The mother glanced at us occasionally, calm and unbothered, while the cub explored the world around us.  Beyond the wildlife, it was also the human characters and their culture that pierced my soul. Smiling faces, non-stop joking, and great Brazilian vibes awaited me before and after every workday. It‚Äôs rare that I get to experience such a strong culture from both humans and animals on an assignment. This was one of those experiences that reminded me why I fell in love with photography in the first place. | The Pantanal: Jaguar sightings, stunning wetlands, and rich Pantaneiro traditions‚ÄîBrazil‚Äôs Pantanal is calling. ‚ÄúWhen you do it with love, nature gives you double.‚Äù These are the wise words from my guide, Branco, in the Northern Pantanal. This is the land of the jaguar. It‚Äôs untamed, unpredictable, and unapologetically wild, a place where silence is broken by the call of a roaring big cat or the splash of a kingfisher. For a soul longing to connect with its biological roots, this is Brazil‚Äôs river of life.  My whole life, I waited to come back home and explore what it means to be Brazilian. I‚Äôve traversed the globe chasing stories, seeking out the raw and the real, but coming here felt different. In the Northern Pantanal, the animals are in charge and that feels like home. No two days are the same, and each wildlife encounter is something to write home about. I could barely ease the tension on my shutter finger as each bend in the river revealed one of nature‚Äôs secrets.  Here, nature doesn‚Äôt just show up, it shows off. It‚Äôs vibrant, abundant, and world-class. And if you show up with love, it rewards you, double. | The Pantanal: Jaguar sightings, stunning wetlands, and rich Pantaneiro traditions‚ÄîBrazil‚Äôs Pantanal is calling. Photos by @francescolastrucci | I landed on the fertile, volcanic island of Pantelleria‚Äîsituated between Sicily and Tunisia‚Äîto photograph the caper harvest. Arabs who settled here in the ninth century introduced the architectural and farming techniques that have become the island‚Äôs heritage. The lava formations and cliffs are battered by waves, and sirocco winds can blow in so fiercely from Africa that, over the centuries, the islanders developed unique and organic agricultural techniques, characterized by dwarf grapevines, olive trees, and low caper bushes that are harvested at the beginning of summer. Once one of the world's largest inland bodies of water, the Aral Sea has receded dramatically since the 1960s because of massive Soviet-era irrigation projects that diverted its lifelines‚Äîthe Amu Darya and Syr Darya Rivers‚Äîto support large-scale cotton farming. What remains is a transformed landscape, where stones that previously touched water are now exposed to the desert wind.

Photo by @daisygilardini | As we know, light is everything in photography. A seemingly dull landscape can transform into a stunning image in the right light.  During an expedition in Antarctica, we decided to try a late landing at Georges Point, on Rong√© Island, even though the cloud cover didn‚Äôt look favorable for a sunset. I always say to my students that the first rule in photography is ‚ÄúBe there,‚Äù and so we went.  Around 10:30 p.m., with the wind picking up and feeling a sudden chill in my bones, I was about to give up when, packing my gear, I took a last look behind me. I saw an opening in the thick clouds and decided to stay another 15 minutes‚Äîjust enough time for the magic to happen!  Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

Tucked beneath the scorching sands of Australia's Simpson Desert, Coober Pedy is no ordinary town‚Äîit's a subterranean haven where thousands live beneath the surface to escape the blistering heat above. National Geographic Explorer Tamara Merino's unexpected discovery of this underground community sparked a passion to explore other hidden cave societies worldwide. From Turkey to Tunisia, she found refuge from harsh climates, as well as enduring traditions shaped by resilience and ingenuity. But with modernization encroaching, these cave societies are gradually fading‚Äîtaking with them invaluable lessons about sustainable living and the art of embracing change without erasing the past. Photos by Aaron Huey @argonautphoto | Seattle has been my home for 20 years, and I‚Äôm still surprised by how fast you can go from city streets to tide pools, from express lanes to towering trees. I recently spent a few days revisiting the places that pull me back to them, the places that slow me down and wake me up when I need to step away from a life with so many screens.  1. At Kubota Garden, you can wander the hidden Necklace of Ponds, where spring brings a kaleidoscope of flowers that makes it hard to leave. 2. Seward Park, another south-end favorite of mine, offers winding trails beneath old-growth cedars, where the air shifts and time slows enough for you to hear a symphony of birdsong. It‚Äôs just a few miles from downtown but quiet enough to forget where you are. 3. In West Seattle, you can kayak straight into a postcard of the skyline while watching the city unfold with every stroke of your paddle.  4. At Alki, with its small-town feel, be sure to walk the beaches, where driftwood lines the shore and a lighthouse keeps watch at the point. 5. And at Golden Gardens in Ballard, sunsets over the Cascades, more often than not, come with a show of seals surfacing just feet from the shore, all within view of campfires and picnics in the sand. These places aren‚Äôt far. But they feel as if they are. And sometimes that‚Äôs enough.   See more of Aaron‚Äôs photos at the link in bio. | Discover Seattle: Mother Nature‚Äôs City. From shimmering waters and nearby forests to world-class dining and hotels, here city and nature live in harmony. @visitseattle

Photo by @paoloverzone | Over the years, I‚Äôve had the chance to visit Greece many times. Still, during my most recent journey, I truly discovered the awe-inspiring landscape of Meteora, nestled in the region of Thessaly. This surreal and magical formation of towering rock columns dates back more than 65 million years, shaped by ancient geological forces and gradual erosion.  Wandering through Meteora today is like stepping into a suspended space where nature, history, and spirituality are connected. From the ninth century onward, hermit monks sought refuge in the cliffs, drawn by the promise of isolation and introspection. Their presence slowly evolved into a more structured monastic community. By the 16th century, Meteora had become a thriving spiritual hub, with 24 monasteries perched among the cliffs, marking a golden age of Orthodox monastic life. Six sites remain active today. Four are inhabited by monks, while the remaining two serve as convents for nuns, with about 67 residents in total.  Recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage site, Meteora is a marvel of natural history and a profound emblem of faith, perseverance, and cultural legacy in Greece.   Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @daisygilardini | The Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard lies midway between mainland Norway and the North Pole. It's one of the last real Arctic wildernesses, with breathtaking landscapes that teem with wildlife: polar bears, foxes, reindeer, walruses, whales, and all sorts of birdlife. Almost 60% of the archipelago is covered by glacier ice, which unfortunately‚Äîas everywhere else on the planet‚Äîis disappearing because of climate change. I photographed this blue iceberg while cruising one of the many wonderful fjords. Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

It's not just kissing swans anymore. Towel art has risen to a whole new level. First popularized by Carnival Cruise Line in the 1980s, today, cruise and resort guests can design their own creations in guided towel art classes taught by seasoned staff. But how did the art form of origami make its way to the hospitality industry?   While many scholars believe that the invention of paper in China coincided with the first attempts at paper folding, it was the Japanese who made origami, originally known as orikata, a large part of their culture. It wasn‚Äôt until the Edo period that origami became more widespread. Today, the art of origami inspires advancements in fields like architecture, medicine, biology, and robotics as well as... towel art!   Learn more about towel art at the link in bio.  Photographs by @davidbrandongeeting

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Mountains remind us how small we really are, never more so than in the Dolomites. Photo by @nicholesobecki | The nature of sand, which behaves at times like a liquid, at times like a gas, and at times like a solid, has long intrigued scientists and engineers. Nature‚Äôs finest sculptures, they were created by cycles of ice ages and thaws that occurred millions of years ago. The geological relics likely took thousands of years to form‚Äîthough the wind erosion that gave them their fantastic shapes will eventually wear them back down to more subdued forms. Photo by @daisygilardini | During my latest expedition to Greenland‚Äôs Scoresby Sound, we decided to photograph our ship, the 94-year-old, three-masted schooner S/V Rembrandt van Rijn, sailing among icebergs. What looked at first to be an easy task turned out to be a demanding and time-consuming effort. The Rembrandt is a tall ship, a traditionally rigged sailing vessel, which means all the sails have to be lifted manually, without electrical winches. Once the sails were up, the challenge was to board a Zodiac while the ship was moving and hope for a bit of breeze, so that the sails are nicely rounded, and for some photogenic icebergs both in the foreground and background. After an hour or so of bouncing around in the Zodiac feeling dizzy and seasick, it all came together! Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

Video by @jodymacdonaldphoto | High above the Kathmandu Valley, the Swayambhunath Stupa keeps a watchful eye‚Äîliterally. Its all-seeing eyes cast outward in every direction, watching, remembering. Locally it's known as the Monkey Temple, and for good reason. The sacred stillness is often interrupted by mischievous monkeys swinging through the ancient courtyards. Pilgrims circle the stupa in clockwise meditation, while the monkeys try to steal both snacks and serenity.  Believed to have emerged spontaneously from a lotus bloom, this 2,000-year-old shrine is one of Nepal‚Äôs oldest and arguably one of its most alive. Prayer flags whip in the wind. Butter lamps flicker. Life, death, and rebirth all swirl together here.  I‚Äôve stood here many times, but never without pausing to think about what these painted eyes have witnessed. Empires rising and crumbling. Kings and rebels. Monks and misfits. So many stories that never made it into the history books.  My favorite time to visit is at sunset, when the gold around the stupa catches the last light of the day. For a few fleeting minutes, it doesn‚Äôt just shine; it glows. The chaos softens. The valley quiets, and in that stillness, it feels like the stupa is reminding me that while everything changes, something here is still watching.   Follow me @jodymacdonaldphoto to see more from my adventures and travels around the world.

While documenting cave societies, Nat Geo Explorer @tamaramerino_photography captured this footage of the cliffs that shelter Petra. Carved over 2,000 years ago, it was once a thriving trading hub at the heart of the Nabataean empire. Hewn from sandstone cliffs, its most iconic structure, the Treasury, is part of an expansive city sculpted into the desert rock. Though the Jordanian government relocated many Bedouin families in the 1980s to preserve the site, a small group of the Semahin tribe remains in the surrounding valley.  Learn more about these cave societies and their enduring traditions at the link in bio.  Video by Tamara Merino

#AD  Photos by @Jonathan_Irish | To escape and refresh from the bustle of Tokyo, I traveled to nearby Hakone to practice Zazen meditation, soak in a traditional hot spring, and gaze upon (and capture) the iconic Mount Fuji. It was a perfect break from the city! 1) The views of majestic Mount Fuji from atop Mount Taikan, located in the town of Hakone, are some of the best you can see. I was fortunate that the fog lifted on this often shy mountain, and I could make a lifelong dream of seeing it a reality. 2) Traditional teahouses along the pilgrimage route to Edo (Tokyo‚Äôs former name) were often smoke-filled houses that welcomed travelers inside. The central fire was used to warm the entire house, and warm teas and hearty snacks were offered, a welcome respite from an arduous journey on foot. 3) Japanese teamaking, known as Sado or ‚Äúthe way of the tea,‚Äù is considered a meditative practice. A warm cup of amazake tea, with a healthy mochi rice cake, would have warmed travelers (just as it warmed me) on their way to Tokyo.  4) Surrounded by lush greenery and forest, Fukuzumiro in Hakone is a serene onsen, which means ‚Äúhot spring‚Äù in Japanese. The big windows, roaring river nearby, and green forest make one feel very relaxed while still enjoying the warmth and comfort of the indoors.  5) A private onsen experience is not to be missed in Hakone. I spent about 45 minutes soaking in this natural hot spring, surrounded by the forest, and I‚Äôve rarely felt as relaxed as I did after this soak. 6) Jyosen-ji, in Hakone, is a Soto Zen Buddhist temple originally founded in 1583. Today you can practice Zazen meditation with the monk, Orihashi-san. I spent 20 minutes meditating, under his direction, in silence, and it was a profound experience. Orihashi-san, captured here, is a quiet and very welcoming monk who is also an excellent chef! #AD  Photos by @Jonathan_Irish | Japan has a tradition of expert craftsmanship. My recent Tokyo photo assignment allowed me to explore this culture of craft through visits to a museum dedicated to the art of bonsai, an upscale coffee tasting experience, and learning centuries-old woodblock printing techniques. 1) With over 1,000 bonsai trees on display, Tokyo‚Äôs Shunkaen Bonsai Museum is perhaps one of the most tranquil places to see these incredible trees. 2) Kobayashi-san, a bonsai master, expertly trims a bonsai tree that is hundreds of years old. Bonsai is the art of cultivating and shaping miniature trees into beautiful forms, and Kobayashi-san has been practicing for decades. 3) At Koffee Mameya Kakeru, one can opt for a regular coffee drink or try a coffee omakase, which is what I did. Omakase, which translates to "I'll leave it up to you" in Japanese, is an experience where you entrust the chef to select and prepare a multicourse event. Here, that concept is translated into expertly crafted coffee paired with delectable appetizers.  4) Heart-shaped foam is one of the treats you‚Äôll see when enjoying one of Koffee Mameya Kakeru‚Äôs delicious drinks. 5) I came to Yukiko Takahashi, a sixth-generation owner of the studio, to learn the art of Edo-period, or ukiyo-e, woodblock printing. Dating back to the 17th century, this technique has been perfected over generations, with the 160-year-old Takahashi family business continuing the tradition. I was honored to learn about this beautiful art form from Takahashi-san. 6) Woodblock prints are made by pressing paper onto uniquely engraved blocks of wood layered with ink, each representing a different color or element of the final print. Under Takahashi-san‚Äôs eye, I created the displayed version of Katsushika Hokusai‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Great Wave,‚Äù one of the best-known woodblock prints. For an amateur, I was quite proud of the result! Within the next decade, China hopes to become a global leader in protected nature reserves, creating a network of wilderness that would be three times the size of the U.S. system.  Although China only created its first national park four years ago‚Äîit claims that by 2035 it will have 49 parks covering 272 million acres. China has already opened five national parks, totaling 57 million acres. Collectively, the parks span alpine peaks, tropical rainforests, remote glaciers, vast deserts, and high-altitude wetlands. They also protect rare animals like the giant panda, Siberian tiger, and Asian elephant.   While domestic tourists flock to China‚Äôs wilderness destinations, few foreigners follow suit. Instead, most international visitors focus on China‚Äôs giant, historic cities, like Beijing, Shanghai, and Xi‚Äôan. But that could change as China expands its park system.   Learn more about the country's effort to become world-renowned for nature-based tourism at the link in bio.  Photograph by @amivitale, Nat Geo Image Collection

Photo by @daisygilardini | Eastern Greenland's Scoresby Sound is one of the biggest fjord systems in the world. It's vast. Its main body is roughly 70 miles (110 kilometers) long and spreads out into a series of side fjords and islets that cover some 15,000 square miles (38,000 square kilometers).  The large glaciers found all along these fjords produce a massive number of icebergs. The icebergs in the fjords are particularly active because the system creates its own circular currents. The icebergs move constantly as they're flushed out into open water. Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories.

#AD  Photos by @Jonathan_Irish | Tokyo markets are a hub of activity, food, and cultural expression. On a recent photo assignment to this vibrant city, I had so much fun exploring the markets in search of small delicacies, unique street food, and quality handicrafts. 1) You‚Äôd almost never find Kissa Mako, a small second-floor shop focused on quality coffee and Japanese broth, if you weren‚Äôt in the know. But having found it, I can say without a doubt I enjoyed one fine cup of coffee. 2) A variety of kitchen knives are lined up on display, representing different styles and shapes that are best suited for certain culinary tasks, such as chopping vegetables and cutting meat. 3) My knife purchase from my new friend, Ishikawa-san, included the opportunity to engrave my name in Japanese katakana (symbolic characters). 4) No stop to the Tsukiji Outer Market in Tokyo is complete without trying strawberry daifuku‚Äïa red bean paste‚Äìstuffed mochi (in flavors ranging from chocolate to mango) topped with a large local strawberry. This traditional Japanese sweet was a real treat! 5) One of the best places to try tamagoyaki (a sweet egg omelet served on a stick) is at Marutake in the Tsukiji Outer Market. This delicious street food is shown here, just seconds before I happily devoured it. It‚Äôs a must-try when adventuring in Tokyo! 6) At Tanaka Shoten one can try ‚Äúkasuzuke‚Äù‚Äîfish preserved in the paste leftover from making sake. One of the first steps in the process is to lightly salt the fish, in this case, fresh salmon. The result is a rich, complex flavor unlike anything I‚Äôve ever tasted before. Delicious! Photo by Linh Pham @phamhaduylinh | A Hmong family harvests rice in Hau Thao village within the Hoang Lien Son mountain range in Lao Cai Province, Vietnam. Nestled in the northwestern corner of the country, Hoang Lien Son, an eastern extension of the Himalaya, is not only the backbone of Vietnam's topography but also a haven for diverse wildlife and ethnic minorities like the Hmong, Xa Pho, Tay, Kinh, and Dao. Towering over the region is Fan Si Pan, Vietnam's highest peak at 3,147 meters (10,325 feet), offering breathtaking views and accessible via cable car or a challenging multiday trek. The lush slopes of this range, located within Hoang Lien National Park, host more than 2,000 plant species and a variety of fauna, making it a captivating destination.

Photos by @paoloverzone | Each year in May, the French city of Arles hosts the F√™te des Gardians, a vibrant celebration honoring St. George, the revered patron saint of horsemen. This festive occasion draws crowds from across the picturesque Camargue region, eager to partake in the procession through the city streets alongside the elegantly attired Arl√©siennes in their traditional garb. The Gardians, akin to cowboys in French culture, proudly showcase their heritage.  The distinctive Arl√©sienne dress, originating in the mid-18th century, symbolizes a bold assertion of independence by the women of Arles. Seeking to distinguish themselves from their counterparts elsewhere in France, they adopted a style inspired by the fashionable trends of Paris at the time. Remarkably, this attire endures to this day as a proud emblem of Arles's unique cultural identity. Amidst the festivities, Gardians and Arl√©siennes converge upon the historic Roman amphitheater for a grand spectacle, enriching the celebration with displays of equestrian prowess and traditional performances.  Follow me @paoloverzone for more photos and stories.

Photo by @daisygilardini | Morning sunlight streams through the dense canopy of the Great Bear Rainforest in coastal British Columbia, illuminating the heart of one of the world‚Äôs most remarkable ecosystems.  The Pacific Northwest temperate rainforest stretches along the coastline from California, Oregon, and Washington State up to British Columbia‚Äîand in broader definitions even includes southeast Alaska and parts of Wyoming and Montana. This region represents one of the largest biomasses on Earth.  Apex predators such as black bears, grizzlies, Kermode bears, wolves, mountain lions, bobcats, lynxes, and coyotes thrive here, while salmon serve as a vital connection between the ocean and forest. Returning to their birth rivers to spawn, salmon bring essential nutrients like nitrogen that sustain the towering, ancient trees of this lush, biodiverse landscape.  Follow me @DaisyGilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

Over two decades ago, a group of paddlers established the @northernforestcanoetrail, or NFCT, a connected group of waterways that allowed canoers and kayakers to paddle from New York's Adirondack Mountains to northern Maine. The trail is inspired by ancient routes used by Indigenous communities such as the Haudenosaunee Confederacy and Algonquin people, and later became vital to the expansion of the trade and timber industries in the 1600s. Pictured here is the Browns Tract Inlet in upstate New York‚Äîone of over 80 rivers, streams, lakes, and ponds that make up the NFCT. Video by @michaelgeorge | This rata forest is the most stunning example of crown shyness I have ever seen. It is so precise, multiple people messaged me asking if it was computer generated. It‚Äôs not fake, but it would be nearly impossible to see this forest in real life. It‚Äôs found on Enderby Island, one of the most remote places on the planet. Close to 300 miles (480 km) south of New Zealand‚Äôs mainland, Enderby is part of the Auckland Islands and one of the rare pest-free islands where endemic species can thrive without fear of being killed by the countless invasive mammals people brought to this part of the world. Yellow-eyed penguins can be found on Enderby, as well as New Zealand sea lions and birds with songs that resemble video-game sound effects. If you turn your sound on, you can hear one from a bellbird.  For those bewildered by the term ‚Äúcrown shyness,‚Äù this phenomenon of certain tree species occurs when the trees‚Äô crowns do not touch each other, forming a distinct pattern among their canopies. If you‚Äôd like to learn more insights into the natural world, follow along @michaelgeorge.

Photo by @michaelgeorge | Bermuda‚Äôs most thrilling performers are the Gombey dancers. Adorned in vibrant costumes, the Gombeys perform throughout the year during holidays and at major island events. The tradition dates back to the early 1800s and blends African, British, Native American, and Caribbean influences, reflecting the island‚Äôs diverse heritage. On a recent trip, I had a chance to watch them perform in the streets of Hamilton, Bermuda‚Äôs capital. At one point, they fully stopped traffic. As the dancers took turns executing elaborate moves to the beat of drums and other instruments, a line of cars and motorbikes backed up quickly. Rather than see this as an inconvenience, the drivers pulled out their cameras and jumped out of their cars to join the celebration. The community‚Äôs love and respect for this uniquely Bermudian tradition was powerful to witness. See more photos from my trip to Bermuda at the link in bio. | From pink-sand beaches to island adventures, @bermuda is your next great escape. Photo by @daisygilardini | The world‚Äôs northernmost emperor penguin colony is found in the Weddell Sea close to Snow Hill Island, off the east coast of the Antarctic Peninsula. Every year, roughly 4,000 pairs of emperor penguins gather on the pack ice off the island‚Äôs coast to breed.  Even though the Snow Hill Island colony is the closest to South America, reaching it is no easy task. Contrary to all other species of penguins, emperors breed during the Antarctic winter (Northern Hemisphere's summer). To reach the colony, you need an icebreaker with helicopters on board. In past visits I‚Äôve had the privilege to work aboard the icebreaker Kapitan Khlebnikov. I managed to take this image at the end of a fantastic day on the ice with these amazing birds, just as the sky was turning from blue to purple to pink.   Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

Periods of time lasting thousands, millions, or even billions of years might seem unfathomable. So Mark Chen (@markchentx), a photographer and teacher in Houston, decided to ‚Äúvisualize this very mysterious idea of deep time‚Äù in more relatable terms: the stars over our heads and the rocks under foot.  Since 2022, he‚Äôs been hiking into wild places, including national parks, at night and deploying a custom-made projector to layer NASA images of star systems onto iconic natural formations in split-second bursts. Each resulting photograph features an earthly setting roughly as old, in years, as the stars‚Äô distance from Earth in light years.  This blend of geological and galactic perspectives, capturing ‚Äúhow our planet has coexisted with the universe,‚Äù is now part of an ongoing series he calls Pilgrimage of Light. By comparison, we humans have been here for only a flash.  Learn more about Mark's mission and see the results for yourself in more detail at the link in bio.  üì∏ 1 - This star cluster some 28,000 light-years from Earth appears on trees at the base of Half Dome, an impressive cliff carved by glaciers moving through Yosemite Valley during multiple ice ages, the last of which was 30,000 years ago.  üì∏ 2 - Sediments within the dry lake bed that forms Bryce Canyon first appeared 30 million years ago, about the time when M104, also known as the Sombrero galaxy, emitted the light seen in this Hubble telescope image.  üì∏ 3 - With snow falling, photographer Mark Chen cast an image of star cluster NGC 3324 beneath the lights of the South Rim‚Äôs Grand Canyon Village. The cluster‚Äôs proximity to Earth, 9,260 light-years, loosely corresponds to how long ago humans started living in settlements.

Photo by @jessicasample | Quaking aspens are among North America's most common deciduous trees, turning vibrant yellow in the fall. Here they're seen reflected in Jenny Lake in Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming.  Each tree in an aspen grove is connected to a single root system, allowing new trunks to grow from underground roots. This means many trees share the same genetics. While trunks can live up to a century, the root systems may be hundreds or thousands of years old.

Photo by @MichaelGeorge | You‚Äôll find the world‚Äôs tallest palm trees in Colombia‚Äôs Cocora Valley, where the wax palms can grow up to 200 feet. My partner is half Colombian but grew up in the United States. In 2023 we spent two weeks visiting Colombia to reconnect him with the country. From Bogot√° to Minca, every place was beautiful in its own way. But the highlight was Salento, the nearest town to the Cocora Valley. For landscape photographers, the sunrise light here is nothing short of magical.  3. Nevada‚Äôs oldest saloon doesn‚Äôt just feel historic; it is history. From the creaky wooden floors to the diamond-dust mirror, walking though Genoa Bar is like stepping into the pages of a history book.  4. The Reno Sauna Club is where retro design meets functional relaxation. After a long day, this was exactly what I needed.  5. Riding the Flume Trail means pedaling for the view‚Äîand it‚Äôs worth every turn. Bonus points if you catch it at sunset, when the pink light transforms the sheer granite cliff as you ride beneath it.  6. Paddling a clear kayak over Lake Tahoe was a one-of-a-kind experience. The water was so transparent that it felt as if I were suspended within it. There were nine births in captivity, as the ibex adapted to the climate conditions in their new habitat, while three females managed to breed in the wild, which attests to the project‚Äôs success. The escarpment looms over a pristine forest of juniper trees, where weaverbirds tend to their young, but this landscape has not always been so idyllic. Photo by @paoloverzone | The Pyramid of Djoser, situated in the ancient burial ground of Saqqara in Egypt, is a remarkable testament to architectural innovation and cultural significance. Often called the Step Pyramid, it was built in the 27th century B.C., during the reign of Pharaoh Djoser of the 3rd dynasty.  Architect Imhotep, a polymath and visionary, is credited with designing and building this pyramid. Imhotep's architectural brilliance transformed traditional mastaba tombs into a monumental stepped structure, setting the stage for the evolution of pyramid construction in Egypt. Imhotep's multidisciplinary skills spanned medicine, engineering, and artistry, which played a pivotal role in his ability to conceptualize and oversee the construction of this monument.  The Step Pyramid, rising six tiers high, was intended to serve as a grand funerary complex for Pharaoh Djoser, symbolizing his eternal journey and showcasing the kingdom's economic and architectural prowess. The complex includes courtyards, temples, shrines, and a vast underground labyrinthine structure, all built with limestone and adorned with intricate carvings and murals.  Imhotep's ingenuity is evident in the architectural and engineering techniques employed: a complex set of corridors and chambers, precise measurement systems, and advanced construction methods. The Step Pyramid reflects the ancient Egyptians' deep spiritual beliefs about the afterlife and is a testament to their ability to transform artistic vision into monumental reality.   Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @francescolastrucci | Light from the sunset makes its way through the clouds and paints the cliffs of Jordan's Wadi Dana. The canyon marks the first leg of the journey that will take me from Dana to Petra in a 4-day adventure through the desert. The 15th-century mountain village of Dana, built in Ottoman style in an area that has been inhabited for 4,000 years, is perched on the edge of the canyon and sits near the Dana Biosphere Reserve, a complex, precious, and rich ecosystem that is now preserved and regulated.   Jordan‚Äôs endless network of trails was ambitiously redesigned in 2015 in the form of the epic 45-day, 419-mile-long (675 kilometers) Jordan Trail, cutting across the length of Jordan from its far north to the Red Sea. One of the most beautiful sections, Dana to Petra is becoming increasingly popular thanks to a wide range of landscapes and ecosystems and the balance of humans with nature.   Follow me @francescolastrucci for more places, daily life, and stories around the world.

What will travel look like in 2025?  "Destination dupes" are expected to be one of the biggest trends. Already increasingly popular on social media, users suggest cheaper, less crowded alternatives to popular destinations‚Äîlike taking a trip to Albania rather than Greece.  Experts also expect to see more changes in the way we plan our trips, from using AI tools to help organize the ultimate getaway to opting for sleeper trains rather than airplanes. Photos by Michaela Skovranova @mishkusk | Yowjab (Montgomery Reef) on Dambimangari Country formed around 1.8 billion years ago and is recognized as one of the most significant geological marine environments in the Kimberley, Western Australia. The reef is a compacted sand plateau with a surface of thick algal growth covering an area of over 400 sq km (155 sq mi), making it the world‚Äôs largest inshore reef.  The tidal range around the reef can be up to 10 meters (33 feet). A shallow lagoon drains with every tide, which encourages the growth of coral and algae that accumulate over the years. It is during these strong tidal flows that Yowjab creates a spectacular sight attracting an abundance of wildlife and birdlife that come and feed in the shallows.

Photos by @martinedstrom | The simple life. The people of Sweden are good at it. All you need is an old log cabin, some forest outside the window‚Äîand a sauna. If ever there were a recipe for Swedish mindfulness, those three things would surely be in it. I photographed these images as part of a travel assignment to capture the trend of "nature living," where people look for the opposite of luxury, wanting instead a simple vacation away from it all. And, I must say, I completely understand where they're coming from. Follow @martinedstrom for more travel tips from Sweden and the Nordics.

Linh Pham @phamhaduylinh | Hmong children walk to Lao Chai Village in the Muong Hoa Valley, within the Hoang Lien Son Range. Nestled in the northwestern corner of Vietnam, the range, an eastern extension of the Himalaya, is not only the backbone of the country's topography but also a haven for diverse wildlife and for ethnic minorities like the Hmong, Xa Pho, Tay, Kinh, and Dao. Towering over the region is Mount Fansipan, Vietnam's highest peak at 10,312 feet (3,143 meters). Accessible via cable car or a challenging multiday trek, it offers breathtaking views. The lush slopes of the mountains in the Hoang Lien Son National Park host a variety of animals and more than 2,000 plant species, making the park a captivating destination.

Photos by @taylorglenn | On a trip in 2023 down the Colorado River where it flows through the Grand Canyon, we experienced an incredible transition of seasons as spring began to take hold. Flowering cacti and wildflowers began to emerge. The grasses, nourished by rainfall, became electric green, providing a bounty for desert bighorn sheep. Trout began to spawn in side creeks, including the mouth of Havasu Creek. Waterfalls ran steadily with excess flow. These contrasts with the rugged landscape were extraordinary. We often think of the desert as devoid of life, but there are many incredible plants and animals thriving in these harsh environments.   Please follow me @taylorglenn for more from the incredible Grand Canyon National Park and beyond.

Photos by @kiliiiyuyan | While on assignment in Greenland‚Äôs high Arctic, I photographed Greenland sled dogs and puppies. Sled dogs are important friends and working companions, and to keep the working breed strong, dogs of other breeds cannot be imported to the northern Greenland region. In Qaanaaq, where there are fewer than a dozen (expensive) snowmobiles, Greenland dogs carry Inughuit hunters and supplies across the sea ice for most of the year. One amazing part of this ancient system is that both humans and dogs are fueled by the occasional seal caught along the way, rather than by using fossil fuels imported from a world away. Qaanaamiut (the people of Qaanaaq) are deeply and intentionally tied to their traditional way of life, which has resulted in the sustainability of wildlife and people in one of the most beautiful and difficult parts of the world.   Follow me, @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the Arctic and beyond.

Those who visit will get the chance to see the cathedral in a way few ever have before, with historic treasures now presented alongside new creations by contemporary artists. Photo by Spencer Millsap @spono | The crystal clear waters of the Raja Ampat archipelago host what might be the most biodiverse reef system in the world, with more than 1,300 coral reef fish species and 600 hard corals. Raja Ampat, or Four Kings, is made up of over 1,500 small islands in more than 4.5 million hectares of protected waters.

Photo by @amritachandradas | At sunset, Patan's Durbar Square in Nepal unveils a mesmerizing tableau of history and artistry. This UNESCO World Heritage site enchants visitors with its elegant courtyards, stately palaces, and ancient temples adorned with intricate stone carvings. Amid the lively markets that surround it, the square resonates with the echoes of Nepal's cultural legacy. In the gentle glow of the setting sun, one can't help but marvel at the resilience of this historic site, which is still under restoration following the devastating earthquake of 2015. Even from a distance, glimpses of ongoing renewal add a poignant layer to the square's timeless charm, highlighting both its enduring splendor and the community's dedication to preserving its rich heritage. Please follow me @amritachandradas for more insight into my work and travels.

Video by Rena Effendi (@renaeffendiphoto) | Amid the terraces of farmland that cascade from the mountains of Jeb Al Soudah, I met one of Saudi Arabia‚Äôs most prominent sporting families. Ali Asiri told me he was the only athlete in his village community when he was growing up in Soudah. But today, his son Fawaz Asiri is an Olympian and international sportsman, who represents the country‚Äôs top sports club, Al Shabab, where he also trains young cyclists, some of whom now compete in the national teams of Saudi Arabia. I watched them cycle along the serpentine roads in the high peaks of Soudah, where the shortage of oxygen due to high altitude is a great way to build athletic endurance. ‚ÄúStrength starts in the mind, not the muscle,‚Äù Fawaz told me, underscoring the values of family and community as the main pillars of support here. On a cliff overhanging a stunning valley, I also met a paragliding and climbing enthusiast, Abdul Bari Muhammad al Abdullah. Native to Jeb al Soudah, he sees these mountains as the launchpad for a life of adventure and sports, calling them his ‚Äúnature playground.‚Äù | Discover the untamed beauty of #SoudahPeaks. Adventure awaits nature lovers. Immerse yourself in breathtaking landscapes, diverse wildlife, and thrilling altitude. Unveil Saudi Arabia‚Äôs hidden gem.

Photo by @jessicasample | The whitewashed houses of Santorini were first painted with a lime-and-water mixture in the 1930s to combat a cholera outbreak and reflect intense sunlight, keeping interiors cool. The government mandated the use of lime for its disinfectant properties. The distinctive blue domes and accents were later added using paint made from locally sourced volcanic ash, resulting in the striking contrast that defines Santorini today.

Photo by @daisygilardini | British Columbia‚Äôs Mount Assiniboine Provincial Park is a photographer‚Äôs paradise. It‚Äôs part of the Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks UNESCO World Heritage site, which straddles North America‚Äôs Continental Divide.  At 11,870 feet (3,618 meters), Mount Assiniboine is often referred to as the Canadian Matterhorn for its resemblance to the famous Swiss peak.  This location has been on my bucket list since I moved to Canada from Switzerland 15 years ago. As I usually spend my summer in the Arctic, though, I never managed to visit it.   I was lucky to finally spend a few days hiking Mount Assiniboine Provincial Park‚Äôs wonderful trails during the height of the wildflower blooming season in August 2023. I love the Swiss Alps ‚Ä¶ and the Matterhorn is really unique. But I have to admit that I fell in love with this place!  Follow me @DaisyGilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

Photo by @paoloverzone | The Bent Pyramid, in Saqqara, Egypt, is an iconic ancient structure built around 2600 B.C., during the rule of Pharaoh Sneferu, founder of the Old Kingdom's Fourth Dynasty. It is one of the earliest examples of pyramid construction and is named for its unique double-angle design. This architectural innovation marks a transition in pyramid construction techniques between step pyramids and the later smooth-sided ones and reflects the experimentation and learning of ancient Egyptian builders in their quest to create monumental tombs for their pharaohs. It is a testament to the evolving mastery of pyramid construction in ancient Egypt.  Sneferu initiated several architectural innovations and built multiple pyramids during his reign.

Photos by @ladzinski | Autumn, with its changing colors, is perhaps one of the most fleeting times in the Rocky Mountains. As temperatures drop, deciduous trees stop their food-making process, prompting chlorophyll to break down, morphing lush green to spectra of yellow, orange, and red. Throughout Colorado, groves of aspen trees can be found, with the highest densities growing along the western portions of the Continental Divide where the mountains descend into the Great Basin desert. These iconic trees transform the mountainous landscape into a world of yellow-gold, and when pressed against the blue skies, they deliver inviting scenes of complementary color. These photos were all taken throughout the Aspen Valley during peak color.

Photos by @michaelgeorge | There are few places where you can experience a 360-degree view that feels like another planet. Blue Mesa is a small part of the Painted Desert inside the Petrified Forest National Park in northeast Arizona. A 1-mile trail snakes through the unique land formations that look as if they were hand-sculpted by someone long ago. This part of Arizona often has cloudless skies (as you can see here), and the stark blue adds to the surreality of the landscape. These conical blue-purple-gray mounds, part of an environment that's more than 200 million years old, get their color from bentonite clay. For more photos from my travels, follow along @michaelgeorge.

Photos by @jonathankingston | Machu Picchu, Peru: Classic view or hidden perspective?   On my first visit to the National Geographic Image Collection in Washington, D.C., I was invited to see the original photographs of Machu Picchu captured by American explorer Hiram Bingham III in 1911. Wanderlust gripped me as I donned white cloth gloves and held the century-old black-and-white photographs.  Bingham‚Äôs were the first of countless images of Machu Picchu. Photos by @kiliiiyuyan | Penguins are the most populous large animals in the Antarctic, having become highly specialized krill and fish eaters that have lost the ability to fly. Some penguin nesting colonies number tens of thousands of birds. Despite this success, only the emperor penguin overwinters in Antarctica. The other penguin species migrate north during the cold season.   Follow me, @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the polar regions and beyond.

Photo by @amivitale | West African giraffes browse in Niger‚Äôs Giraffe Zone, a region where giraffes and humans coexist. Critically endangered, only about 600 West African giraffes remain, up from a low of 49 in the wild‚Äîa notable conservation success.  In 2018 the Giraffe Conservation Foundation, in partnership with Niger‚Äôs government and other organizations, relocated eight of these threatened giraffes from the Giraffe Zone to Gadabedji Biosphere Reserve, where they had been absent for over 50 years. This is a hopeful development for a species facing a silent extinction across Africa, with their numbers plummeting nearly 40 percent in the past three decades. Scientists are now conducting major studies to understand the causes of this decline and find solutions. Empowering Indigenous communities will be crucial to saving these and other iconic species worldwide.

Photo by @paoloverzone | While on assignment for a @natgeoexpeditions trip in Egypt, I caught a day's last rays of light in Luxor. The Nile holds paramount historical significance in the region, dating back to ancient Egypt. This majestic river was the lifeblood of the civilization, providing fertile soil for agriculture and enabling the growth of the flourishing society that built iconic monuments like the temples of Luxor and Karnak. The annual inundation of the Nile brought prosperity and allowed the Egyptians to harness its waters for irrigation and produce bountiful harvests. Luxor, once known as Thebes, became a center of pharaonic power and a hub of culture and religion, thanks to the Nile's vital role. Even today, the Nile continues to symbolize endurance and heritage for the people of Luxor. #NatGeoExpeditions

Photo by @chrisburkard | Planning this Alberta trip was a long process in 2014. Sometimes we're exploring the topography on Google Earth, checking trail maps and videos, or just studying photographs to examine everything we can, looking into any place that might be of interest.   It‚Äôs difficult to pick just one spot that stood out to me. But Mount Assiniboine, also unofficially known as the Matterhorn of the Rockies, is one of them. It's this giant pyramid-shaped mountain located on the Great Divide, the highest peak in the southern continental ranges of the Canadian Rockies. This place is unique in so many ways that you don‚Äôt see in my home state of California. It has a rugged and raw aesthetic that has been forever ingrained in my memory.

Top rock climbers @tommycaldwell and @alexhonnold biked, hiked, and boated nearly 2,600 miles from Colorado to Alaska‚Äîbefore they got to the mountain many considered unclimbable, Devils Thumb.  The climbers are interested in ‚Äúecopointing,‚Äù a term popularized by some European climbers to describe a human-powered adventure that produces zero fossil fuel emissions. Their goal was to make it to Devils Thumb with minimal help from motors.   The first two weeks of their journey took them through Montana and Wyoming, where they devoured rainbows, shared meals, traversed dirt roads and cattle trails alongside wild horses, and maintained their hangboard routine in preparation for their climb.  To read more about their expedition, go to the link in bio. And don‚Äôt miss #TheDevilsClimb premiering Thursday, October 17 at 9/8c on @natgeotv. Stream next day on @DisneyPlus and @hulu. In 1914, Sir Ernest Shackleton embarked on a voyage to cross the Antarctic. In 2022, the wreckage of the Endurance was finally discovered. Photo by Reuben Wu @reuben | These striking red rock formations, with their distinctive shapes and white markings, are part of the Hopi Reservation in Arizona. The red-and-white coloring is due to variations in mineral content, with red hues formed by oxidized iron (rust) and white areas composed of sandstone or light-colored minerals like quartz or calcium carbonate. Over millions of years, wind and water erosion sculpted these layers into the otherworldly formations we see today. Access to this area is restricted and allowed only with a Hopi guide. Please respect the land and do not trespass. For more photos and behind-the-scenes insights, follow me @reuben.

National Geographic's Best of the World 2025 Readers' Choice finalists are here‚Äîand they need your vote! üåé   This year's finalists are:   Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam: An ever-evolving cityscape that balances its contradictions with grace‚Äîhistory and modernity, street food and haute cuisine, Ho Chi Minh City has it all.   New Orleans, U.S.: There's more to the Big Easy than just Mardi Gras. Whether you're visiting for jazz, art, history, or food, New Orleans is guaranteed to charm.  Bodrum, Turkey: A seaside paradise with chic modernity, Bodrum has reinvented itself as one of the hippest locations on the Mediterranean, offering perfect escapes whether you want to party or relax.  Cusco, Peru: Marrying Incan stonework with 16th-century colonial architecture, the gateway to Machu Picchu offers cultural delights and myriad excursions for those seeking adventure.   Sarajevo, Bosnia & Herzegovina: Whether walking labyrinthine streets to find bazaars, mosques, and basement bars or exploring its Olympic mountains, Sarajevo's rich history extends beyond the shadows of the 20th century.  Let us know which of these destinations is calling your name in the comments, and help us decide which will be crowned "Readers' Choice" as part of Nat Geo's Best of the World 2025.  Responses will be considered through Thursday, October 17 at 5:00pm ET. Time-lapse video and recorded ambient sound by @babaktafreshi | It was a wondrous morning in Puerto Rico, with a rare pairing of a comet and the moon an hour before sunrise on September 30. I was on Vieques island for the Life at Night Atlas‚Äîa National Geographic Society project‚Äîand to document the approaching comet A3 (Tsuchinshan-Atlas), which was visible in the morning sky. I could see the comet with unaided eyes, but the images revealed much more. On October 10 and 11, the comet will emerge in the evening sky and is expected to become much brighter. On the prime nights of October 12 and 13, when it is closest to Earth, the comet will be most visible in the Northern Hemisphere and the tropics.   Follow me @babaktafreshi for more updates on this and other celestial wonders.

Fifteen ibexes were transported to the Red Rock area of Soudah peaks in 2021 from a captive breeding center northwest of Riyadh. Photo by @MichaelGeorge | It is a strange phenomenon to be surprised by the northern lights. This week, as has happened a few times this year, intense geomagnetic storms have given a show in areas where the northern lights typically can‚Äôt be seen. NOAA‚Äôs Space Weather Prediction Center explains that this celestial event is happening because the sun is arriving at the peak of its 11-year cycle. The northern lights have even been seen in places with intense light pollution, like New York City. I had never seen the lights except faintly, when a camera was needed to really see the colors. This week was something completely different. What initially looked like a delicate sunrise soon became a 180-degree light show of colorful fire. The pinks and greens were visible to the naked eye and eventually began to pulse, as if an electric force field was activating above. This was a lesson in using the camera I had, since the only one on me was my phone. The storms are expected to continue until October 13. Keep your eye to the sky, and you just might find yourself in a moment of wonder.
You may not like it, but this is what peak performance looks like ‚õ∞Ô∏è  #NatGeoQueens, #HostilePlanet, and #TheHiddenKingdomsOfChina are streaming now on @DisneyPlus.

Words by @amivitale | This was a first of its kind photography project where @kiliiiyuyan, Matthieu Paley (@paleyphoto) and I documented our own stories in different regions of Canada.‚ÄØI had the privilege of visiting the Yukon and Northwest Territories and discovered how these lands are governed by both the biggest and smallest‚Äîthe grizzly and the mosquito‚Äîand by the extremes of subarctic seasons. The people I met, the landscapes I visited, and the lessons I learned will stay with me forever.   The sheer magnificence of this place, with its granite peaks piercing the alpine sky, brought me to tears. It reminded me of the crucial connection we all need with wilderness for our own well-being. In these raw, untouched spaces, we discover a deeper sense of ourselves and a renewed appreciation for the natural world. I returned not only in awe of its magnificence, but also acutely aware of its fragility and how we inhabit these spaces.  Discover more about the "Season of Wonder" at the link in bio. | Embrace Canada's rich cultures, vast landscapes, and heartwarming interactions from coast to coast @ExploreCanada

Words by @michaelgeorge | There‚Äôs nothing more invigorating than traveling with water as my guide. Ontario, Canada is one of the best places to do this as the thriving province holds an abundance of freshwater. I set off to drive across the region, learning about Ontario through its endless pools of blue. My first stop is one of the most challenging, learning to do yoga on a stand-up paddleboard with Toronto Island SUP. Carved with estuaries filled with beavers, herons, and boathouses, Ward‚Äôs Island in Toronto feels much more remote than it is. My next stop is Sauble Beach, which has a photogenic welcome sign and long stretches of coastline to walk Lake Huron. In Killbear Provincial Park, I catalog an irresistible array of water activities. To my left are families kayaking, paddleboarding, and swimming. To my right are jet skis, boats, and a line of thrill seekers jumping into the water. One of my favorite days is learning how to properly canoe with Tori Baird of Paddle Like a Girl. We spend the day on the Magnetawan River and have lunch on a small, uninhabited island. The finale of my trip is the one and only Niagara Falls, which seems to have a perpetual rainbow welcoming visitors into its beauty and strength. Despite traveling the world, I‚Äôve never found this many ways to indulge my senses through water.   Learn more at the link in bio. | Explore Ontario, Canada‚Äôs stunning waterways, diverse cultures, and scenic landscapes. From vibrant city life to serene natural beauty, there‚Äôs always something new to discover. #DiscoverOn @Ontariotravel

If you're traveling to Europe, you might soon be subject to the new Entry/Exit System (EES)‚Äîwhat does that mean for travelers?  Launching on November 10, the scheme will be adopted by 29 countries, including all EU members except Cyprus and Ireland. The new automated system aims to capture fingerprints and photographs of visitors which would be checked on every visit, prompting fears over long queues and additional processing times.  Whether you're traveling by plane, car, ferry, or rail, these new measures will likely affect you, so it's best to brush up on the system before going. Sweeping across the central Spanish plain to the Sierra de Guadarrama, the breathtaking Greater Madrid region surrounding the capital city is home to national parks, a rich biosphere, antiquity sites, and ancient legends as colossal as the mountains. Photos by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | I‚Äôve just returned from an assignment with National Geographic magazine visiting the beautiful caves of the Yucatan Peninsula. I was completely in awe of the crystal clear water. This stunningly turquoise water is the aquifer and main water source for the people, vegetation, and animals that live in the region. Unfortunately, a lot of the natural world here, including hundreds of cenotes‚Äîthe deep pools shown in these images‚Äîcould be under threat from the construction of the Tren Maya railway in Mexico.

Video by Rena Effendi (@renaeffendiphoto) | Located at the crossroads of centuries-old trading routes, the Soudah region has preserved its deep culture and history. Here, I met the Flowermen, who gather herbs at dawn in the hills around Soudah and sit in the shade of acacia trees to play music, cook and make essabh‚Äîthe flower crowns, which they wear as part of their traditional tribal attire. Abou Wael, the tribal elder, told me that although the flower crowns once had the practical purpose of covering farmers‚Äô heads from the sun, they now became an integral part of their tribal identity.   In Soudah, I tasted aseed, the most delicious bread with ghee and honey baked by Amal Turshi, who told me that she was eight years old when her mother taught her how to bake it and that she had already passed the knowledge on to her five daughters.   The traditional local art form of Al Qatt Al Asiri takes its inspiration from the surrounding landscape with its geometric patterns representing the natural elements. Triangles symbolize the mountains; dots represent the harvest of seeds and prosperity. Well-known local artist Fatima Ali Abu Qahas is passing her craft on to the next generations teaching students how to mix natural dyes by hand. | Discover the untamed beauty of #SoudahPeaks. Photos by Matthieu Paley (@paleyphoto) | 1. Inside the church of the Real Monasterio de San Lorenzo de El Escorial, dappled light and serene quiet highlight the splendor of Spanish Renaissance architecture. Built between 1563 and 1584 under King Philip II, this UNESCO World Heritage Site is a majestic complex that functioned as both a royal palace and a monastery.  2. Oscar Jim√©nez, whose family has bred horses for generations, took me on a ride through Guadarrama National Park, showcasing one of his impressive Andalusian horses. These are big horses! Known for their grace and endurance, they perfectly embody the elegance and strength of Spain‚Äôs equestrian heritage.  3. This is the view from the Chair of Philip II (Silla de Felipe II) near El Escorial in the Sierra Guadarrama. From this iconic stone chair, King Philip II reportedly oversaw the construction of the nearby monastery. Today, it provides a stunning panorama of the mountains and valley, reflecting the king‚Äôs likely appreciation for both natural beauty and architectural grandeur.  4. Getting lost in Madrid was quite the adventure! Here, passersby descend the historic Arco de Cuchilleros, a 17th-century staircase that connects Plaza Mayor with the vibrant streets below. Once a gateway for tradesmen and knife makers, this archway stands as a lasting symbol of the city‚Äôs rich history, where commerce, tradition, and daily life have intertwined for centuries.  5. Photos by @macstonephoto | South Carolina's Congaree National Park hosts the largest old-growth bottomland hardwood forest in the southeastern United States. Its dark skies and undisturbed soils are the perfect stage for a spectacular show that unfolds every spring. After dusk, a special firefly (Photuris frontalis) emerges to begin its courtship. The male's bioluminescent flash just above the ground attracts females. What makes these fireflies‚Äîoften called snappy syncs‚Äîspecial is that they miraculously blink in unison. Witnessing this phenomenon feels like seeing the heartbeat of the swamp. Researchers are still trying to unlock the secrets of how such small insects can do this over relatively large distances. Pictured here, synchronous fireflies pulse throughout a 4-minute single exposure.   For more stories from wetlands and swamps, follow @macstonephoto.

You may have gone picking for apples and blueberries, but have you heard about pawpaws?  These hidden edible treasures look like green mangoes but taste like a banana crossed with pineapple and mango‚Äîmaking for a tropical whirlwind of flavors. Native to 26 states, North America‚Äôs largest edible fruit is ripe for picking in late summer. Because of its short harvest season and shelf life, pawpaw fruits are difficult to distribute and remain largely unfamiliar to most Americans. While mainly overlooked, pawpaws are having something of a renaissance. Photo by Rena Effendi @renaeffendiphoto | Artist Fatima Ali Abu Qahas practices the art of Al-Qatt Al-Asiri using traditional patterns and natural dyes made by hand, and passes it onto the next generation of artists. Al-Qatt is an art form of geometric patterns, miniatures and cohesive ornaments applied traditionally by women to the walls and ceilings of homes. Local herbs and other natural ingredients, such as pomegranate peel and acacia tree leaves, are used in the making of the dyes. Each painstakingly executed ornament carries a story, a narrative about the people, their daily activities and the natural elements around them. Geometric shapes portray community rituals around agriculture and daily life. Triangles represent a family unit, but also trees and mountains, while the dots symbolize seeds. | Discover the untamed beauty of #SoudahPeaks. Adventure awaits nature lovers. Santorini may be considered the star of the Cyclades, but an increase in tourists on a lesser-known Greek island is proving to be a strong alternative.  The ethereal charm of Milos, Greece, makes it a wonderful destination for travelers with its ancient archeological sites, quaint villages, delicious seafood fare, and postcard-perfect views.  Historically avoided due to its industrial reputation, Milos is a place that deserves to be explored. Words by @michaelgeorge | It would take weeks to fully explore all there is to discover in and around the Casco Bay region of Maine. That‚Äôs why I went in armed with a bucket list, starting with Harraseeket Lunch and Lobster. Mainers have a commitment to harvesting and preparing impeccable cuisine. There are many restaurants where you can watch the fishermen come and go, delivering a meal that could only be fresher if you caught it yourself. From Scarborough to Freeport, state parks and sanctuaries seamlessly blend with the urban areas in and around Portland; it‚Äôs like traveling through portals into the natural world. One of my favorite portals leads to Wolfe‚Äôs Neck Woods State Park. If you‚Äôre interested in history, such as shipbuilding and Civil War‚Äìera forts, there are plenty of places to visit, like Fort Gorges, an architectural marvel just off the coast of Portland. Lastly, I can‚Äôt say exactly why it is, but lighthouses always fuel my imagination. It might be the countless poetic stories from literature, or the romantic idea of a lonely figure living by the sea. A lesser known gem is Spring Point Ledge Lighthouse. Catch it at sunset, and you can toss your bucket list over your shoulder. It doesn‚Äôt get better than that. | From coastal cities with vibrant art scenes to camping under the stars, Maine offers an abundance of charm, history, and adventure for all types of travelers looking for the perfect escape. #MaineThing @visitmaine

Photos and videos by @babaktafreshi | Fireflies in Sugar Hill, New Hampshire, near the White Mountains, glow above lupine flowers in peak bloom in June. It was almost a paradise, except for all the hungry mosquitoes that were chasing me on this windless, humid night.  These images and video were captured for Life at Night Atlas, my long-term project with the National Geographic Society (@insidenatgeo). Fireflies are important night pollinators. Their populations have declined worldwide due to pesticide, loss of habitat, and light pollution. Their light signal is for mating, and it stops in the presence of bright artificial light. Fireflies are least affected by motion-sensor and shielded lights. I was happy to see them thriving here.

#AD Photos by @jonathan_irish | I‚Äôve been to Amsterdam many times and have always loved its incredible architecture, endless canals, and the locals‚Äô passion for bicycling. A recent photo assignment let me dive deeper into this vibrant city and left me even more in awe of what is surely one of Europe‚Äôs most fun and interesting places to visit.   1) Centuries-old tall, narrow houses facing the Damrak Canal in central Amsterdam seem crooked when viewed from the street. But in reality, they‚Äôve been slightly tilted for almost as long as they‚Äôve been around.  2) There are more bicycles than people in Amsterdam. Although the city prefers the bikes locked up in designated areas (and not on bridges), you‚Äôd have a hard time finding a bridge without one.  3) One of Amsterdam‚Äôs great treats, and a must-try when visiting the city, is stroopwafel: traditional flat waffle cookies filled with warm caramel. They are heavenly! The oldest active bakery in Amsterdam, Hans Egstorf, has been making these confections since 1898.  4) During twilight‚Äôs blue hour, city lights reflect on the Amstel Canal, one of the city‚Äôs main channels. Words by @michaelgeorge | People usually travel to Maine guided by a sense of adventure. I arrived guided by my stomach. Though lobster and blueberries are the staples, there are countless cuisines to discover up and down the coast.   Eating a whoopie pie is like eating a cookie that‚Äôs been magically turned into a pillow. The texture is divine, which means breaking it open is almost more fun than eating it.   If you‚Äôre looking for a sea-to-table meal that looks like a work of art, deliver yourself to Crown Jewel on Great Diamond Island. The mussels, oysters, and crudo left me wishing I had a second stomach.   You‚Äôll find a special brew in downtown Portland at Burundi Star Coffee. The owner, Jocelyn Kamikazi, grew up in a family of coffee farmers in Burundi, and she sources the beans from her home country.   The freshest lobster I found was at Harraseeket Lunch and Lobster, where guests can look over the railing at the boats coming and going with the day‚Äôs catch. Seeing firsthand the work it takes to harvest each lobster made me even more grateful for this delicious meal.   And finally, the blueberry scone from Standard Baking Co. changed my understanding of what a baked good can be. 10 out of 10, no notes. | From coastal cities with vibrant art scenes to camping under the stars, Maine offers an abundance of charm, history, and adventure for all types of travelers looking for the perfect escape. #MaineThing @visitmaine

Words by @michaelgeorge | Within a short drive of Portland, Maine, there are countless vistas to discover. Here is a small sampling of what I saw after a week of exploring the coastline. Which view is your favorite?   1) An adventurous walk along the rock jetty that leads to Spring Point Ledge Lighthouse is a perfect activity for sunset. 2) Wake up and smell the ocean crashing against the cliffs at Two Lights State Park near Cape Elizabeth. 3) If you need a quick escape into nature, the Fore River Sanctuary offers 85 acres of trails, including Portland‚Äôs only natural waterfall, Jewell Falls. 4) Stroll one of the wooded paths that lead to the rocky coast in Wolfe‚Äôs Neck Woods State Park. 5) Enjoy the Mailboat Tour on a real working boat as it delivers mail, supplies, and *you* to the many islands throughout Casco Bay. 6) Though there are plenty of sandy beaches, nothing beats the sound of waves on the rocks near Cape Elizabeth. 7) Fort Gorges is a spectacular landmark and only a half hour‚Äôs paddle from the shoreline of downtown Portland. | From coastal cities with vibrant art scenes to camping under the stars, Maine offers an abundance of charm, history, and adventure for all types of travelers looking for the perfect escape. #MaineThing @visitmaine

#AD Photos by @Jonathan_Irish | On my recent photo assignment to Dublin, I was blown away by this thriving, colorful, and welcoming city. Whether walking the River Liffey through the heart of the Irish capital, exploring its many neighborhoods, or meeting and laughing with the Dubliners, I found that this city stole my heart.   1) The beloved Ha‚Äôpenny Bridge in Dublin crosses the River Liffey near the Temple Bar district. Built in 1816, the bridge originally had a toll of a ha‚Äôpenny, or halfpenny. Today it‚Äôs free to stroll across, which I did many times on this trip!  2) Phoenix Park is the largest urban park not only in Ireland but also in all of Europe. A substantial herd of fallow deer call this park home and can often be found lounging in the open grass or wandering in the forest.   3) The Temple Bar district in central Dublin is known for its many pubs and its lively street scene. No trip to Dublin is complete without a visit to the famous neighborhood, which caters to tourists and locals alike. My favorite time to go to the Temple Bar district was at its busiest hours (weekend evenings) to really experience the craziness (and excitement) of Dublin pub life.  4) The medieval Christ Church Cathedral has been a cornerstone of Dublin city life for more than a thousand years. Established in A.D. 1030, it has survived a millennium of calm, wars, and transitions, hosting kings, queens, and presidents and millions of people who desire to be a small part of its storied history.  5) Near the gardens of the Dublin Castle, in the center of the city, you‚Äôll find a row of very colorful buildings. Many people think Dublin is gray and full of stone, but my experience was quite different‚ÄîI found Dublin to be full of color! Photos by Rena Effendi @renaeffendiphoto | The Kel√¢at M'Gouna Rose Festival takes place each spring in Morocco as roses are harvested in a valley at the foot of the Atlas Mountains amid ancient fortresses and castles made of mud brick. Before rose water and rose oil became sought-after commodities, local farmers planted rosebushes as hedges to prevent animals from entering their orchards. Here, roses are picked in the early morning hours‚Äîbefore the buds open, yet after they are warmed by the sun. This method ensures preservation of the fragrance and results in oil with a more distinct scent. Women sort the roses by hand and distill them into oil and rose water, which is a thriving local industry. During the last three days of April, a beauty pageant is staged where a panel of judges selects the queen of roses, the most beautiful rose picker of the season. The rose queen is paraded in a horse-drawn carriage along the main road of Kel√¢at M'Gouna. Each year, thousands of people gather to watch the parade at the Rose Festival, which includes a procession of traditional Amazigh dancers and musicians. Learn more at the link in bio.

Photos by @michaelgeorge | As we crossed the Drake Passage on my first expedition to Antarctica, a fellow staff member told me the oft-repeated line: ‚ÄúPeople come here for the wildlife but come back for the ice.‚Äù Knowing how desperately excited I was to see a penguin, I scoffed. This series of images, taken while traveling with @natgeoexpeditions, speaks to that saying and the infinite forms the ice can take: towering above you, crumbling around you, built like small towers, or patterned perfectly by the waves below. It is like watching a campfire. You‚Äôve seen it a million times, but it never fails to draw you in. For more photos and writing from my travels, follow along @michaelgeorge.

Photo by Chris Burkard @chrisburkard | Why are glaciers ice blue? Ice absorbs red (long) wavelengths, while short (blue) wavelengths are scattered and transmitted, producing the color commonly seen along Iceland‚Äôs southern coast.  K√∂tluj√∂kull is an offshoot of M√Ωrdalsj√∂kull, a glacier that's home to one of the magnificent ice caves accessible along the south coast of the island throughout the year. Formed by water freezing under the glacier, the multidimensional contours cast unique shadows reflecting natural light and giving the iconic blue ice space to shine. On a trip with my family last summer, I photographed the Katla Ice Cave with a 16-35mm lens, hoping to capture the true scale of the arch and the feeling of standing beneath it.

Photo by @martinedstrom | Ever since I saw how vividly people paint their houses in Tasiilaq in eastern Greenland, I've wondered why we don't all do the same. At first, I thought these colors were used to add a bit of brightness and vibrance to the monochromatic Arctic setting‚Äîwhich would have been smart in itself. But as it turns out, it's part of an old, even smarter system where each color signifies something: where to find a specific type of service, for example. Yellow was used for hospitals and anything health-related, while green houses contained a radio or something to do with communications. As I recall, red houses are most common, signifying something to do with the church but also relating to trade. A smart system for remote locations, right? Imagine trying to find your way through a snowstorm in the dark Arctic winter‚Ä¶ This makes things so much easier. Perhaps we could use the system to make our own cities smarter and easier to navigate.
