Captured by @mikemezphoto, this beautiful footage of the Northern Lights was filmed in Kensington, Kansas between the evening of May 11 and the early predawn hours of May 12, when the solar storm was at its strongest.  "It was a moment in which I honestly couldn‚Äôt believe my eyes. I‚Äôve shot the aurora borealis in many Arctic locations, and never would have thought I‚Äôd be shooting it in such a low latitude as Kansas. Blues, pinks, reds, greens were all visible to the naked eye and at times, dancing directly overhead. The solar storm began to become visible right after sunset and lasted all the way until the sunrise twilight. To be able to witness and experience such a historical event in space weather is going to be hard to top."

Photo by @paoloverzone | The Pyramid of Djoser, situated in the ancient burial ground of Saqqara in Egypt, is a remarkable testament to architectural innovation and cultural significance. Often called the Step Pyramid, it was built in the 27th century B.C., during the reign of Pharaoh Djoser of the 3rd dynasty.  Architect Imhotep, a polymath and visionary, is credited with designing and building this pyramid. Imhotep's architectural brilliance transformed traditional mastaba tombs into a monumental stepped structure, setting the stage for the evolution of pyramid construction in Egypt. Imhotep's multidisciplinary skills spanned medicine, engineering, and artistry, which played a pivotal role in his ability to conceptualize and oversee the construction of this monument.  The Step Pyramid, rising six tiers high, was intended to serve as a grand funerary complex for Pharaoh Djoser, symbolizing his eternal journey and showcasing the kingdom's economic and architectural prowess. The complex includes courtyards, temples, shrines, and a vast underground labyrinthine structure, all built with limestone and adorned with intricate carvings and murals.  Imhotep's ingenuity is evident in the architectural and engineering techniques employed: a complex set of corridors and chambers, precise measurement systems, and advanced construction methods. The Step Pyramid reflects the ancient Egyptians' deep spiritual beliefs about the afterlife and is a testament to their ability to transform artistic vision into monumental reality.   Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Photo by @tasneemalsultan | The Gharameel rock formations, located just outside AlUla, Saudi Arabia, captivate visitors with their awe-inspiring beauty. Rising dramatically from the desert floor, these natural wonders were carved by millions of years of wind and water and showcase intricate patterns and textures. With hues ranging from golden yellow to deep red, the rocks create a mesmerizing spectacle against the backdrop of the starry night sky. For the local community, they hold cultural significance; ancient inscriptions and petroglyphs found on their surfaces add to their historical and archaeological importance. Offering a surreal experience in the heart of the Arabian desert, Gharameel is a must-visit destination for nature lovers and history enthusiasts alike. | Experience the extraordinary monuments and ancient history in the vast desert of #AlUla.

Photos and video by @taylorglenn | Frames made with a 600mm telephoto lens show various stages of the total eclipse on April 8, 2024, from northern Maine. It is difficult to put the viewing experience into words, and I am grateful to have witnessed it. Those who were lucky enough to see it know exactly what I mean. Frames #1 and #6 feature the "diamond ring" effect that happens seconds before and after totality. In frame #3 you can see solar prominences arcing from the surface of the sun. Frame #5 captures Baily's beads, bright dots of light on the edge of the orb. Frames #2 and #7 show moments of partiality. The video in the final frame is a high-speed look at the full three and a half minutes of totality. There is so much to take in; I'm still processing such an incredible sight. #eclipse2024

Check out one of our favorite photos by Isley Reust @isleyreust from our #NGPhotographerChallenge!   ‚ÄúEvery year, I travel to East Greenland to document either expeditions or scientific research surveys. Photo by @daisygilardini | I visited this wonderful cave in the Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard in early spring when temperatures were still well below freezing. Glacier caves are carved by the erosion of water that flows under the glacier.  Glaciers are constantly shifting and changing shape. The blue coloration of cave ice is due to the lack of air bubbles in the ice. The pressure of the glacier‚Äôs weight over thousands of years squeezes out the air. The now pure ice absorbs longer wavelengths of light, such as red and yellow, and reflects blue and green, the wavelengths that are visible to our eyes.  It's never recommended to visit glacial caves in summer. The combination of ice melt and glacial motion can be unpredictable‚Äîand dangerous.  Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories behind the scenes.

Who is ready to view the total solar eclipse tomorrow? ‚òÄÔ∏èüåëüåéüòé  The premier celestial event of the year will be a breathtaking total solar eclipse on April 8 that will darken the skies for millions of watchers across North America as the moon completely covers the sun.  The path of totality, where the entire disk of the sun is blotted out by the moon, will sweep across four states of Mexico, 15 U.S. states running from Texas to Maine, and five Canadian provinces in the eastern part of the country. Any locations outside the narrow path of totality will only see a partial eclipse.  One report estimates one to four million people will travel to see this year‚Äôs solar eclipse.  Are you traveling to be within the path of totality to watch the total solar eclipse?  Photograph by @chamiltonjames of a total solar eclipse seen from Jackson Hole, Wyoming, in 2017. #ourHOME

Directly in the path of totality, Niagara Falls will offer views of a total solar eclipse, and is included as one of our #BestOfTheWorld 2024 top travel experiences.  For about three and a half minutes, beginning at approximately 3:18 p.m. on April 8, the sky will darken over the thunderous cataract as the moon crosses between Earth and the sun‚Äîwhich won‚Äôt occur again in the contiguous U.S. until 2044.  On the U.S. side of the falls, Terrapin Point, Prospect Point, and the Observation Tower will be prime viewing areas (if clouds stay away). From the Canadian side, an excellent vantage point is Table Rock.  üåà A side bonus: The sunny-day rainbow that hovers above the falls will become pink. Venture to iconic places and beyond what you already know with National Geographic.  üìçMACHU PICCHU A wonder of the natural world, Machu Picchu continues to reveal clues to the lost civilizations of our past. In 1912, with the support of National Geographic, explorer Hiram Bingham set off to investigate rumors of ancient Inca ruins in Peru and stumbled on one of the greatest archaeological finds of the 20th century: Machu Picchu.   üìçMOUNT EVEREST The first American expedition to Mt. Everest, partially funded by National Geographic in 1963, proved to be the most successful Everest mission in a decade, blazing a new trail to the summit along the way.  üìçRMS TITANIC In 1985, with the help of technology designed by the National Geographic Society, professor of oceanography Robert Ballard found the remains of the RMS Titanic. The discovery shed new light on this enduring tragedy 73 years after the ship sank four days into its maiden voyage.   üåç For a limited time, receive a free special edition tote featuring the coordinates of an iconic place when you purchase a new digital subscription. The new, nearly 200-mile Pekoe Trail‚Äîwhich winds through Sri Lanka‚Äôs central highlands, passing remote villages and tea estates‚Äîwas voted the #BestOfTheWorld 2024 Reader‚Äôs Choice Winner.  Sri Lanka is virtually synonymous with tea. The island nation is one of the world‚Äôs top producers of tea leaves. Now visitors can trace the footsteps of historic planters on the new trail, which is also the country‚Äôs first long-distance walking route.  Starting just outside Kandy, the trail follows the 19th-century tracks upon which workers and horse-drawn carts transported freshly plucked leaves. Hikers can even stop to take a cooking class or savor a cup of aromatic Ceylon tea.  Discover more at the link in bio.   Photograph by Tom Sigler, @weekend_hiker

Photo by @chrisburkard | Life in the Kuril Islands is a true testament to the adaptability of nature. Despite harsh conditions, grass clings to the steep slopes and marine life thrives in the nutrient-rich waters surrounding these shores. Having access to the islands via a research vessel after an invite from my good friend @renan_ozturk, I couldn't pass up the opportunity to document such a pristine environment so rarely seen with human eyes. We arrived at the chain of islands hours, maybe even minutes, after a volcanic eruption. We heard the hissing of hot earth cooling in the ocean and saw wildlife significantly disturbed from its natural rhythm. The remoteness of these islands keeps most visitors away, save for occasional scientists or military personnel, making for an otherworldly feeling when you set foot on them.

Photos by Matthieu Paley @paleyphoto | On my journey across Canada, a country I knew little about, I found myself welcomed with open arms and lovely accents. Following the coast around Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Qu√©bec, I was really taken by the hospitality, diversity, and the general relaxed, warm attitude of the Canadian people.  1. Elemental power rings through these massive natural structures. The Hopewell Rocks, sometimes referred to as sea stacks, were created by tidal erosion‚Äîand as the Bay of Fundy has some of the most extreme tidal shifts in the world, it‚Äôs no wonder these are so dramatic.  2. At the end of Cape Breton in Nova Scotia, I was told of pilot whales that cruise St Lawrence Bay. I didn‚Äôt hold out too much hope of spotting them, but I was too excited not give it a try! Perched on top of a boat, guess spotted the first whale? Yes, yours truly. A moment of glory I won‚Äôt forget‚Ä¶  3. Virginie Provencher of Les Montagnards de Charlevoix welcomed me surrounded by her horses, unfazed by the rain. It was a true immersion in this cowgirl‚Äôs life, and she obviously has strong emotional ties to the animals she so lovingly cares for. We eventually went riding into the surrounding mountains filled with the red, yellow, and orange fall colors.  4. Arriving in Montr√©al in the late afternoon, we went straight to look at the famous Farine Five Roses sign‚Äîa fixture of the skyline since the late 1940‚Äôs that has survived to this day! It felt like something straight out of a movie.  5. As a French national, I have a soft spot for the Qu√©b√©cois, French-speaking community and the way they maintain connection to their heritage. Meeting with Chef Emilie B√©gin at FoodLab in Montr√©al, we realized we shared common roots in Normandy, a love for cr√®me fraiche, and food in general! She made me discover Mujjol caviar, a mix of mullet and herring roes that marries beautifully with gravlax; a fresh vinaigrette of cucumber and delicious balsamic vinegar. I will be back for more! Read more about my journey at the link in bio. | Embrace Canada‚Äôs rich cultures, vast landscapes, and heartwarming interactions from coast to coast @ExploreCanada.

Photo by @michaelgeorge | I have completed countless hikes in my life, but none were as succinctly intense as the Reinebringen trail in Lofoten, Norway. Imagine you‚Äôre visiting a picturesque village and someone says you can get a spectacular view from above. The only catch is that you need to climb 1,566 steps that rise 448 meters (1,470 feet) above sea level. For context, that is 200 feet (60 meters) higher than the Empire State Building. I rarely publish photos with a crooked horizon, but this view captures the endorphins and exhaustion I felt upon reaching the top. For some historical context‚Äîthe hiking path used to be extremely steep and slippery. In 2016, a project to build the stone stairway brought Sherpas from Nepal who are experts at constructing trails in mountainous terrain. The project was funded by various sources, including crowdfunding campaigns and private donors. Now the trail is much more accessible‚Äîbut not any less difficult.

Video by @daisygilardini | A glorious sunrise seen while cruising among giant icebergs in Greenland. One of the things I love the most while on assignment in the polar regions is the isolation from the modern world. I simply love to wake up just before the sun and get out to breathe the fresh air while observing giant icebergs passing by. Those icebergs might be hundreds, if not thousands, of years old. Once they‚Äôve calved off from the glaciers that produced them, they‚Äôre free to float in the polar waters until they melt completely and become one with the oceans. It‚Äôs in these moments that I realize how important it is to preserve these delicate ecosystems.  Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories from behind the scenes.

Photo by Linh Pham @phamhaduylinh | The village of Lao Chai, located in the Muong Hoa Valley in the Hoang Lien Son mountain range in Lao Cai Province, Vietnam. Nestled in the northwestern corner of Vietnam, the Hoang Lien Son range, an eastern extension of the Himalaya, is not only the backbone of the country's topography but also a haven for diverse wildlife and ethnic minorities like the Hmong, Xa Pho, Tay, Kinh, and Dao. Towering over the region is Mount Fansipan, Vietnam's highest peak at 3,147 meters (10,326 feet), which offers breathtaking views and is accessible via cable car or a challenging multiday trek. The lush slopes of this range, located within Hoang Lien National Park, host more than 2,000 plant species and a variety of fauna, making it a captivating destination.

It was 56 miles (90 kilometers) back to the lodge, and although I was tired and cold the image of this tree warmed my heart. Photo by @acacia.johnson | The sun rises between the Calanais Standing Stones on the Isle of Lewis in Scotland‚Äôs Outer Hebrides. At over 5,000 years old, these mysterious stones predate Stonehenge. They are believed to have been used for ritual activity during the Bronze Age, and possibly as an early astronomical observatory.  In the days and nights I shared with these ancient stones, watching the sun, moon, and stars wheel around them in the vast silence of the ether, it was easy to understand why they‚Äôve captivated people‚Äôs imaginations for eons. They even inspired Disney‚Äôs animated Scottish tale Brave, whose protagonist Merida was guided to her destiny by her own arcane ring of stones. Photographing these megaliths at sunrise, the long shadows they cast over the earth elevated their mythical allure. Click the link in bio to see more of my photos from Scotland. | Be star-struck by Scotland‚Äôs film locations! #ScotlandIsCalling @visitscotland

Photo by @carltonward | This fall my family experienced the Florida Everglades with fifth-generation gladesman Jack Shealy. From the silence of a wooden skiff that he built himself and pushed with a hand-hewn cypress pole, Jack guided us along the Turner River, a waterway flowing through Big Cypress National Preserve toward the Gulf of Mexico. Glades skiffs like Jack‚Äôs have been used by pioneer families for nearly two centuries, providing access to one of the largest wetlands on Earth long before drainage systems and roads started diverting water and paving the way for modern Florida. As we glided amid birds and alligators, Jack gave my family members some time at the helm. In this image, Suzie Ward navigates a narrow section of the river while Jack fends off low branches.   Big Cypress National Preserve, Everglades National Park, and the four million acres (1.6 million hectares) of connected public lands in South Florida ¬≠(an area twice the size of Yellowstone National Park) are conservation lands vital to the Florida Wildlife Corridor and to preserving wild spaces in one of America‚Äôs fastest growing states.

Photo by @MichaelGeorge | Small red fishing huts line up in Lofoten, Norway, as if begging to be photographed. In this image, a kayaker soaks up the view from the water. Lofoten is a popular destination for many reasons‚Äîin summer it attracts hikers and anglers, and in winter it attracts people hoping to see the northern lights above the dramatic landscape. The small town is covered in traditional racks for the drying of cod. If you want to see this in action, the unsalted cod is dried in the spring by cold winds and almost freezing temperatures.

Photos by Reuben Wu @reuben | The imposing monolith of Factory Butte in Utah looms in the soft predawn light; a fresh coat of snow covers its flank.  For this image I used a telephoto lens to fill my entire frame of view, a composition that required not just a specific focal length but also a very specific distance, time of day, and time of year, as well as ideal wintry weather conditions. For more photos and behind-the-scenes details, follow me @reuben.

Photo by @michaelmelford | The South Island of New Zealand is one of those special places in the world that never disappoints. Sir Edmund Hillary trained here for his epic climb of Mount Everest, which stands more than 29,000 feet high (8,800 meters). Photos by @michaelgeorge | Chilean Patagonia‚Äôs Torres del Paine is the rare park where humans are true outsiders in a vast, legitimate wilderness. Though it occupies 930 square miles (2,400 sq km), the park received only 140,000 visitors throughout 2022. Compare that with Zion National Park, where last year close to 4.7 million people explored its 232-square-mile (600-sq-km) expanse.  This image was captured as I traveled over Lago Peho√©, which translates to ‚Äúhidden lake.‚Äù The brilliant color is caused by glacial flour, or rock dust suspended in the water. Prior to visiting Torres del Paine, I presumed all photos I‚Äôd seen of it had the saturation turned up to exaggerate the colors. I was pleasantly surprised that this is not so‚Äîthose colors are precisely how they look. It‚Äôs as if all the natural features that make a landscape beautiful are turned up a notch. In the distance you can see Macizo Paine, a group of mountains that look like broken teeth.

Photo by @erintrieb | Among the many things I love about climbing big peaks are the weather patterns and color shifts that appear through my lens in a single day. Clouds can engulf a slope, causing whiteout conditions with no sight of the horizon, but 10 minutes later the sun can appear, to create perfect bluebird weather. For me, the mountains are the ultimate educator as they provide a flux of constant change and teach me to prepare, adapt, and continue moving forward.  In this image, on Mera Peak in Nepal, climbers descend the glacier‚Äôs northeast-facing slope at about 20,000 feet (6,100 meters). #InternationalMountainDay

Towering over the region is Mount Fansipan, Vietnam's highest peak at 3,147 meters (10,326 feet), which offers breathtaking views and is accessible via cable car or a challenging multiday trek. The lush slopes of this range, located within Hoang Lien National Park, host more than 2,000 plant species and a variety of fauna, making it a captivating destination.

Photo by @simonnorfolkstudio | Tikal stands as one of the largest pre-Columbian sites. It is located in the archaeological region of the Pet√©n Basin in what is now Guatemala. The ruins lie in the tropical rainforests that formed the hearth of lowland Maya civilization. Tikal reached its peak during the Classic period (200 to 900 C.E.). During this time, the city dominated the Maya region militarily, economically, and politically, and saw a succession of at least 33 leaders over a span of 800 years. Studies of hieroglyphic inscriptions found at the site indicate that the city was then known as Yax Mutal or Yax Mutul. The site was added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1979.   Here, the 47-meter (154-foot) Temple 1 (also known as the Temple of Ah Cacao or Temple of the Great Jaguar) is seen from Temple 2. This mortuary pyramid was erected in honor of Jasaw Chan K'awil, who was interred within around 734 C.E. To the left are some of the stelae (carved stone shafts, often sculpted with figures and hieroglyphs) that front the Northern Acropolis. Video by @jonathan_irish | Colorado is home to one of the most beautiful and vibrant displays of fall foliage in the entire country. With snow-capped mountain peaks as the backdrop for this explosion of autumn color, the change of seasons here makes for a truly awe-inspiring view in almost every direction. This year, I traveled to Ouray, Colorado, to explore the backroads and grand vistas near this western mountain town. Situated in a river valley at nearly 8,000 feet (2,500 meters) of elevation, Ouray (pronounced ‚ÄúYOU-ray‚Äù) is surrounded by the San Juan Mountains and flanked by seemingly endless groves of aspen trees. It‚Äôs the perfect location for photographing fall foliage. Photos by @francescolastrucci | Active since the seventh century A.D., the stunning, vast, and intricate site of Hampi, in the Indian state of Karnataka, is a UNESCO World Heritage site famous for its astonishing temples and ruins. Photo by @orsolyahaarberg | See that area that looks like white carpet in this aerial image of a mixed forest in Rondane, Norway? It‚Äôs a thick layer of lichen called Cladonia sp., which covers where the ground is most exposed. The Cladonia species do not tolerate thick snow cover, so they grow in places snow is blown away by wind in the winter. Nearby are autumn-yellow mountain birch (Betula pubescens) and Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris).

Photos by Matthieu Paley (@paleyphoto) | What surprised me most when I visited the Canary Islands was the diversity of the landscapes I encountered across this relatively small archipelago.  On Lanzarote I was impressed by the ingenious technique developed by farmers who cultivate grapes in this arid and volcanic region, which has little precipitation and is famous for its trade winds. They nurture the vines in conical depressions in the soil that are protected by low stone walls. Humidity and rain collect in the cones, allowing the grapes to grow without an irrigation system. Seen from the air, these little craters, called ‚Äúhoyos,‚Äù look like land art!  In Gran Canaria, I walked across the beautifully tranquil Maspalomas Dunes Nature Reserve, its towering sand waves stretching to the sea. It was surreal to experience the seclusion of this desert landscape in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.  The famous Mount Teide volcano looms over the island of Tenerife. To get there, we drove through a rainforest and up into the clouds before emerging to find this incredible view of Teide in its lunar landscape.  Later, we traveled into Gran Canaria‚Äôs interior, and suddenly the road opened up to this amazing view of Roque Bentayga. Located inside an ancient erosion crater, the rock formation is an archaeological landmark, and a place of astronomical worship dating back to Gran Canaria‚Äôs pre-Hispanic inhabitants. | You deserve @spain #VisitSpain  Learn more at the link in bio.

Read more at the link in bio.  Though they died thousands of years ago, hundreds bodies excavated in East Asia‚Äôs Tarim Basin are extremely well-preserved.   The dry, salty environment allowed the bodies to decay slowly, and sometimes minimally. Photograph by Wenying Li, Xinjiang Institute of Cultural Relics and Archaeology

Photo by @kiliiiyuyan | I‚Äôm on assignment in Greenland‚Äôs high Arctic, where Inughuit hunters use kayaks as they have for millennia. It‚Äôs fascinating to me because I am a traditional kayak builder myself and love to see this ancient and sophisticated technology so alive. Inughuit, or northern Greenlandic Inuit, are wedded to their traditional ways of life‚Äîparticularly the use of kayaks and dogsleds. The kayak is part of a hunting system with a hand-thrown harpoon and float line that allowed Inuit peoples to migrate from Siberia and survive a significant climate cooling in Greenland. During that time, Inuit had to adapt to hunting seals and narwhals efficiently. Today it remains the primary way to hunt in open water, and the use of a sophisticated traditional hunting management system alongside quotas ensures that this beautiful homeland will remain sustainably managed for millennia to come.   Follow me, @kiliiiyuyan, for more from the Arctic and beyond.

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | As the last daylight leaves us, the 90-foot-long (27 meter) suspension bridge of the Ivano Dibona via ferrata is silhouetted against a moody Dolomites sky. However, our feelings of being unnerved are nothing next to the emotions felt by the soldiers who moved through this area a hundred years ago. When traveling here late in the day, we risk passing a cold night in the mountains without a sleeping bag‚Äîtrivial compared with what they must have faced.  @natgeointhefield

Photo by @daisygilardini | The Greenland tundra's fall colors are simply mesmerizing. The tundra is a zone of treeless ground usually found north of the Arctic Circle or above the timberline. Trees cannot grow on the tundra because of the strong winds and the permafrost that lies below the surface of the black soil. Plants found in this biome include mosses, lichens, herbs, and dwarf shrubs. As with plants in more temperate climes, fall is a time for change. Shorter daylight hours, together with colder temperatures, cause photosynthesis to slow down and eventually stop. Chlorophyll is what causes leaves to appear green. When it breaks down, other chemicals take over: carotene (responsible for yellow) and anthocyanin (red). The yellows and reds shine through, giving us one of the most beautiful shows in nature to admire.   Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and stories from behind the scenes.

Photo by @paoloverzone | Skagsanden Beach, nestled in the picturesque Lofoten Islands in Norway, is a captivating natural wonder that entices locals and travelers alike. The play of colors across the sky creates a surreal ambiance, casting a spell over those fortunate enough to witness it.   Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Read the full story at the link in bio.  Coyotes look before crossing a street. Black bears know when it‚Äôs trash day. As more scientists study the creatures right under our noses, a consistent message is emerging: Many species are adapting to urban life in unprecedented ways. It‚Äôs a phenomenon happening in urban areas across the United States and around the world. Many mammals that eat a wide variety of foods are moving in and changing their behaviors as they learn urban survival skills. The more we understand the animals living in our midst, ecologists say, the better we can get along with these urban newcomers.  Photograph by Corey Arnold @arni_coraldo

Photo by @sofia_jaramillo5 | Filmmaker and conservationist Jr Rodriguez hikes to a river in the Tetons in Wyoming while working on the movie Wading For Change, about fly-fishing. In Texas where he grew up, Rodriguez learned to fish without fancy gear or vast landscapes as the backdrop. Family and community were always present in his outdoor experiences. His love for the outdoors was solidified alongside his Latinx community and during family outings. Wading for Change shows how passion for the outdoors can blossom through community, regardless of economic status, location, or skin color. The film was recently selected by the National Geographic Short Film Showcase and premiered on  National Geographic's YouTube page on August 16. Follow @sofia_jaramillo5 for more conservation images from around the world.

Photo by @mridulaamin | Spending sunrise in a hot-air balloon over the ruins of Teotihuacan, an ancient Mesoamerican stronghold 30 miles (50 kilometers) from modern-day Mexico City. What fascinates me is that there‚Äôs still so much mystery around this ancient city, including questions about the workings of its multiethnic society, the meaning of its texts, and its original founders. What continues to capture our attention is the practice of human sacrifice to the gods‚Äîan important ritual in pre-Hispanic Mesoamerica. The consecration of the pyramid temples involved collective human sacrifice. Several human remains have been found during excavations. Follow @mridulaamin for photography from around the world.

Some of the most important‚Äîand most endangered‚Äîtidal flats are found surrounding the Yellow Sea along the shores of China and the western side of the Korean peninsula. For decades, people have been transforming them into industrial sites and farms, squeezing them into smaller areas and pushing some species to the brink of extinction. But as science increasingly shows how wetlands like these benefit wildlife and help fight climate change, South Korean scientists and conservationists are gaining momentum in their effort to save and restore what‚Äôs left. The uninterrupted daylight offers a sense of timelessness and allows visitors to engage in various outdoor activities‚Äîfrom hiking and kayaking to fishing and photography‚Äîwhile basking in the gentle warmth of the sun's glow. Photos by Dina Litovsky @dina_litovsky | Earlier this year, I traveled to Fort Worth, Texas, for the first time and was excited to experience the unique cultural heritage of the city. It was packed with people dancing and having drinks and felt like the quintessential place to enjoy the city‚Äôs nightlife. The next day, I discovered a tranquil duck pond in Fort Worth‚Äôs Trinity Park‚Äîa great spot for bird-watching. While I enjoyed all that the city has to offer, my favorite experience in Fort Worth was witnessing the twice-daily longhorn cattle drive along East Exchange Avenue in the Stockyards. Twice a day, drovers on horseback herd longhorn cattle along East Exchange Avenue as crowds look on from the sidewalks. I‚Äôve never seen steers with such big, beautiful horns, and I was thrilled to meet, photograph, and even pet a few before the morning drive. Afterward, I walked over to M.L. Leddy‚Äôs, a famous Western-wear shop. I couldn‚Äôt resist getting a gorgeous, hand-shaped straw hat and photographed one of their craftsmen creating its shape with steam. And since I never miss the chance to experience the nightlife in a new city, after speaking with locals, I ended up at the historic White Elephant Saloon. It was exactly what I was hoping for. The saloon was packed with people dancing and meeting up for drinks. When I left, I met Ricky, a limo driver who was waiting for people to leave the saloon. We chatted, and he let me take his portrait, which is one of my favorites from the trip. The few days I spent in Fort Worth were full of history, culture, and exuberant nightlife. Words by @michaelgeorge | In the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, countless destinations allow you to dive into its wild and natural beauty. Photos by Michael George @michaelgeorge | I never knew the Midwest had a wild side. After years of hearing mythic references to Michigan's Upper Peninsula, I had the chance to see it for myself. Flying in by seaplane, I was greeted by an archipelago packed with outdoor activities, and I even spotted a mama moose with her baby. At first we thought a beluga whale might have been trapped somewhere. We followed the noise and, to our great surprise, discovered that the source was this very old iceberg that was grounded at the bottom of the fjord. The friction and pressure caused by the wind and stiff currents made the iceberg ‚Äúsing.‚Äù We circled it many times, recording the beautiful melody, taking pictures, and creating videos of this amazing piece of natural art.

Photo by @paoloverzone | The meteorite room (Hall 5) of the Natural History Museum Vienna offers an exciting exhibition. Housed in a meticulously designed building in Vienna that embodies a holistic artistic vision, the museum showcases the remarkable diversity of nature, the evolution of our planet, and the development of life and culture throughout human history. Photos by Prasenjeet Yadav @prasen.yadav | In India's Spiti Valley, a message came late in the evening that one of the free-ranging horses had given birth. The horse's owner was really happy, but I could see that the joy was attenuated. After talking to him, I understood that the horse was about 6 miles (10 kilometers) away in the mountains, and it had started snowing. If not brought back to the village, the foal would die of cold, or predators like wolves, snow leopards, or free-ranging dogs would kill it.   So we all left in the blizzard to look for the horse. After many hours of walking, searching, and yelling, we found the horse, and it took a few more hours to restrain her and tie a lead rope. This picture was taken during that process in the snowstorm. The foal survived, and I managed to photograph it again a few days later.   Follow me @prasen.yadav for more photos from the biodiverse states of India.

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | Meteora, a UNESCO World Heritage site in central Greece, is best known for its clifftop monasteries.   For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen.

Photo by @estherhorvath | In Germany's Black Forest National Park, spruce, fir, and beech trees surround the Wilder See, a remote mountain lake. In 1911, the forest around the lake was designated a protected area. Every saw, every axe has been resting there for more than 110 years. Beech-fir primeval forests can accommodate thousands of species from the categories of mushrooms, lichens, mosquitoes, snails, beetles, and mammals alone. Many of these species are dependent on dead wood, which makes up a great part of a primeval forest's total amount of wood.  Please follow @estherhorvath for more stories. Read the full story, "Meet the Marvelous Creatures That Bring Soil to Life," at the link in bio.

Photo by @acacia.johnson | A brown bear cub peeks over its mother in Alaska‚Äôs McNeil River State Game Sanctuary and Refuge. This protected area on the coast of Alaska's Kamishak Bay is home to the largest known gatherings of brown bears on Earth, largely on account of its prolific salmon runs. Due to careful management over the past 50 years, the bears at McNeil River have come to view humans as a neutral presence. A state-run permit program allows small groups of visitors to camp in the sanctuary each summer and see these bears in the wild.   Follow me at @acacia.johnson for more stories from Alaska and beyond.

Photo by @paoloverzone | This is a detail of two seated royal colossi in quartzite (second pylon) at the funerary temple of Amenhotep III in Luxor, Egypt.  This temple was a grand monument built in ancient Egypt during the 18th dynasty. It was dedicated to Pharaoh Amenhotep III and served as a place for his worship and posthumous glorification. The temple complex featured multiple structures, including massive pharaoh statues, a colonnaded court, and several shrines and chapels. Though much of the temple has been destroyed over time, significant restoration efforts have been made by a team of German-Egyptian researchers led by archaeologist Hourig Sourouzian to preserve what remains of this impressive architectural wonder.  Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories, and learn more at the link in bio.

Photo by @justin.jin | Buddhist monks receive alms in the form of glutenous rice from laypeople in Luang Prabang, the ancient capital city of Laos. The city, which lies in a valley at the confluence of the Mekong and Nam Khan Rivers is a UNESCO World Heritage site noted for its preservation of fine Buddhist temples and French colonial buildings. By bringing monks food each day, the faithful invest in their own souls; for the monks, this practice teaches humility. To shoot a picture like this one, you have to arrive at one of the main temples before 5:30 a.m., when the monks file out in a possession.   Follow @justin.jin for more stories and images from around the world.

Photos by @kiliiiyuyan | Dusky dolphins swim in large pods near morning kayakers at Kaikoura, New Zealand. Kaikoura Peninsula hosts great populations of marine mammals at the junction of major currents from subtropical and Antarctic waters, as well as a submarine canyon. Here some 2,000 dolphins live year-round, alongside fur seals and a welcoming community of Maori and other New Zealanders that's centered on ecotourism. The calls of birds and the hum of crickets remind you just how alive the whole landscape really is. This approach of going back to basics has been on the rise for several years. One nature-hostel manager I met while photographing this series put it quite bluntly: "Twenty years ago people said I was crazy for not having satellite TV installed. Now they get mad that there's even cell phone reception. They don't want it."‚Å†  Follow @MartinEdstrom for more travel tips from Sweden and the Nordic region.

Photo by @tasneemalsultan | The magnificent Pyramids of Giza are an enduring symbol of Egypt's rich history and architectural legacy. Built more than 4,500 years ago, these massive structures have withstood the test of time, weathering countless sandstorms and earthquakes. They were built as tombs for the pharaohs, with the largest of them, the Great Pyramid of Khufu, standing at a height of 481 feet (147 meters). To this day, the precise methods used to construct these monuments remain shrouded in mystery, making the Giza Pyramids one of the most intriguing and enigmatic wonders of the world.

Photo by @robert_ormerod | The Knoydart peninsula in the western Highlands has been called Scotland‚Äôs last wilderness. Video by @katieorlinsky | In 1924 the Gila Wilderness, in New Mexico, became the first designated wilderness area in the United States. Where the Rocky Mountains end and the Chihuahan Desert begins, the Gila Wilderness encompasses desert, grasslands, pine forests, 10,000-foot mountain ranges, and one of the largest still undammed rivers in the American West, the Gila. Since 2021, I‚Äôve returned to the region time and time again, exploring its 870 square miles of rugged country on foot, by mule, and on horseback for this month‚Äôs cover story. I got to know Becky and Ysabel Campbell, who own the Gila Hot Springs Ranch and goat farm on the edge of the wilderness, just in time for baby goat season. I embarked on a 10-day backcountry horseback trip with Nat Geo writer Peter Gwin and Nat Geo producer Brian Gutierrez led by Joe Saenz, a Chiracahua Apache guide, activist, and educator. He shared stories by firelight about the famous Chiracahua Apache warrior Geronimo, born and raised along the headwaters of the Gila River. I hiked and camped by myself for the very first time, encountering elk in the high country, seeing trout in the river, and making a new black bear friend. And I looked for mountain lions with legendary houndman Nick Smith and his highly skilled, extremely adorable scent hounds. One dictionary defines ‚Äúwilderness‚Äù as ‚Äúuncultivated, uninhabited, and inhospitable,‚Äù but after spending time with the wonderful people and animals that call this special place home, I know that the Gila Wilderness is none of those things. Read more at the link in bio.

Photos by @kiliiiyuyan | Sometimes a place exceeds all of your expectations. I recently traveled to Austin, Texas, and was blown away by the buzzing energy of the city. Photos by @jimmychin | These landscapes are part of the 15 million acres of wilderness that Kris and Doug Tompkins have protected and preserved over the past 25 years. Their tight-knit group of friends have had a profound impact on the  world, both in conservation and by defining a way of life and ethos to live by.   "Wild Life" is, among other things, a film about friendship. Deep friendship. Friendship with history. Part of the story revolves around a group of friends who grow up together, adventure together, build companies together‚Äîa group of friends who define a lifestyle and ethos for generations ahead. It's been an incredible gift while making "Wild Life" to be able to spend time with some of these extraordinary people, who have made such an impact on my life and the lives of so many others. Here are a few portraits I made of them during filming.  Kristine Tompkins (above) is the founding CEO of Patagonia and co-founder of Tompkins Conservation, which has protected more than 15 million acres (6 million ha) of land in South America.  Yvon Chouinard is a climber, surfer, environmentalist, and founder of Patagonia. He recently gave away his company‚Äî worth $3 billion‚Äîto help fund saving the planet.  Lito Flores is a photographer, filmmaker, and artist. He shot all the footage on the legendary Fun Hogs trip in 1968, which documented Doug Tompkins, Yvon Chouinard, and Dick Dorworth on an intercontinental road trip. They started in Ventura, California, and climbed, skied, and surfed all the way down to Patagonia, where they made the first ascent of the California route on Fitz Roy. Some of this footage can be seen in "Wild Life."  Rick Ridgeway is an author, adventurer, climber, filmmaker, and environmentalist. Rick has authored books and made numerous films about his adventures‚Äîand even coined the term "Seven Summits." He taught me how to film during my first ever National Geographic expedition, a trip in 2002 to  Chang Tang, part of the Tibetan Plateau. Rick was also one of the first Americans to climb K2 without supplemental oxygen, in 1978, which landed him on the cover of "National Geographic."  "Wild Life" is now available to stream on @disneyplus.

Photo by @joshuacogan | Haida carver Stormy Hamar paddles a traditional round-bottom canoe on a summer day last year. ‚Äã‚ÄãPhotos by @jonathankingston | Eight views of the Taj Mahal in Agra, India. I am awestruck every time I visit this symbol of eternal love and devotion built by the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal. The perfect symmetry of the surrounding buildings creates so many different ways to view this masterwork. For a photographer, capturing unique views of the Taj Mahal can be quite a challenge. This iconic monument has been photographed countless times, and it can be difficult to find a fresh perspective or angle that hasn't been seen before. However, despite the challenges, I am always eager to try my best to honor the vision of eternal love and the countless artisans who devoted their time and skills to construct this magnificent building. With every photograph I hope to pay tribute to their incredible craftsmanship and dedication, and to showcase the stunning beauty of this architectural wonder.

Photo by @tobyharriman | Camping is one of my favorite activities during the Alaska summer, especially since the sun is shining for 18-plus hours a day. One of the things I love about Matanuska is that it‚Äôs accessible but still feels special. No matter how many times I‚Äôve visited, I never run out of angles to explore or unique photos to create. I managed to find a spot to pitch my tent on the ridge, and at around 10:30 that night, I captured this twilight perspective of Matanuska emerging from the Talkeetna and Chugach Mountains. | Adobe @Lightroom gives beginner and professional photographers easy tools to edit their photos, no matter where they are.

Photos by @jimmychin | After "Free Solo" and "The Rescue," @chaivasarhelyi and I are incredibly excited to share our latest film, "Wild Life." It follows conservationists Kristine and Doug Tompkins on an epic, decades-spanning love story as wild as the landscapes they dedicated their lives to protecting. Along with Rick Ridgeway and Yvon Chouinard, this tight-knit group‚Äîthe original dirtbag climbers, skiers, and surfers‚Äîdefined a way of life and the ethos for the outdoor adventure and climbing worlds. "Wild Life" explores the power of love and lifelong friendships forged in the mountains, along with finding meaning and how we choose what to hold dear.  Here are some of the landscapes contained in the 15 million acres (6 million ha) Tompkins Conservation has helped protect and preserve. The efforts of Doug and Kris have culminated in the biggest private land donation in history. They created or expanded 17 national parks in their 25 years of conservation work. Their rewilding efforts, now continued by Rewilding Argentina and Rewilding Chile, are aimed at reintroducing threatened species into these incredible landscapes.   "Wild Life" is now streaming on @disneyplus and @hulu. For more on the Tompkins legacy, read the story at the ink in bio.

Video by Mathias Svold @mathiassvold | The ‚ÄúLoneliest Road in America‚Äù is a highway running through Nevada with a few ghost towns along the way. On my first stop out of the car, I narrowly avoided stepping on a rattlesnake. As someone accustomed to living in a big city, I found that being alone with a snake on seemingly never ending dirt roads surrounded by miles of desert initially overwhelmed me.  Gradually, I grew familiar with the beauty of the quiet landscape, and I had the opportunity to meet some locals. They told me that this place provides them with a unique sense of independence and freedom.  Through this journey, I discovered that the Loneliest Road in America isn‚Äôt so lonely after all. It‚Äôs big and vast and seemingly endless, and in that there‚Äôs solitude, yes, but not sadness. In a world where everything is moving at an increasingly fast pace, maybe we all sometimes should drive on a lonely road.  Read more about the "Loneliest Road in America" at the link in bio.

Photo by @jonathankingston | Who knew that eastern Washington held such a hidden treasure? Palouse Falls left me speechless with its stunning and unique landscape. As I worked to capture its beauty in my picture, I searched for a composition that would convey both the story of the massive successive lava flows that blanketed much of eastern Oregon and Washington (known as the Columbia River flood basalts), as well as the enormous ice age flood that carved out the basin that now houses Palouse Falls. After exploring the park for around two hours and experimenting with different lenses, I discovered a high spot above the falls that allowed me to capture the sweeping river and cascading water. Palouse Falls is a true marvel that showcases the incredible natural history of the region. | Adobe @lightroom gives beginner and professional photographers easy tools to edit their photos, no matter where they are.

Photos by @babaktafreshi | A full moon rises above the Taj Mahal at dusk. This World Heritage site of white marble is considered a monument to eternal love. On the five nights each month before, during, and after the full moon, you can visit the Taj Mahal at night, when the marbles shine brightly in the moonlight.

Photo by @gretarybus | William Robbins, a volunteer at the Historic Yates Mill County Park in Wake County, North Carolina, checks the water-powered mechanisms of the gristmill. Every third Saturday, the park hosts live demonstrations, and historical reenactments show how corn was processed as far back as 1756. Video by @joshuacogan | I met Tom Barnes, a fifth-generation rancher, while at the National Cowboy Poetry Gathering in Elko, Nevada, in November 2022. The family, aided by their cattle dogs, worked seamlessly as a unit, moving the horses through the fresh snow to surround the cows and push them up into the sorting pens. There‚Äôs always something powerful about seeing those whose way of life has deep ties to the land. Pouring me a coffee afterward, Tom told me about the lessons he‚Äôs learned from this land and this place. ‚ÄúIt teaches you how to be part of something and feel a part of something. You actually have ties to the ground and land when you put your blood, sweat, and tears in it, so it‚Äôs more than just a place to live and work; you are bonded to it, you have emotional ties to it.‚Äù | This is Nevada‚Äîawe-inspiring, otherworldly, and gloriously unspoiled. Photo by @max.lowe | Antarctica is a remarkable natural wonder of remote wilderness, with countless enigmatic  animals that have come to represent the southern cap of our planet. Ice is the true unsung Antarctic hero though, and is the reason the Southern Ocean is the verdant feeding ground for countless endemic birds, fish, seals, penguins, marine mammals, and more. Within the beauty of the silent bergs that break from the continent's ice shelves lies the secret to life in our oceans: tiny phytoplankton that feed the krill that serve as the base of all our oceans' food systems. Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Yangon, Myanmar, 2015. Yangon was the capital until 2006 and remains an essential commercial hub, with a population exceeding seven million. Once called Rangoon, it is a city of contrasts that pulses with life. Its streets are home to Buddhist temples, colonial buildings, and an eclectic mix of people. On every street corner, vendors sell aromatic and diverse wares, adding to the city's vibrant atmosphere.  In 2015, Myanmar had opened its doors to tourism and was experiencing a wave of change and opportunity. It was a stark contrast to the decades of repression under a military regime that had previously kept the country closed off. But on February 1, 2021, a coup d‚Äôetat was staged by the military, ousting the democratically elected NLD party from power. Since then, Myanmar has shut its borders once again to international travelers, leaving the once vibrant Yangon and the rest of the country inaccessible to tourists. Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens. #myanmar #yangon #temple #pagoda

Photos by @jimrichardsonng | Evening falls over Mar Lodge Estate in early autumn in Scotland's Cairngorms National Park, as the heather is close to its best. That heather is so predominant on the Highland moors is not entirely natural; it's also the result of a couple of centuries of managing the land for the maximum production of grouse. Estates depend on grouse for a fair bit of their income, and grouse, whose numbers climb in areas where there is more heather, were a prime draw of the estate system in the first place. Mar Lodge is one of the estates actively trying to rebalance the ecosystem, looking at ways to bring back more trees to the Highlands. The old stump is symbolic of that loss of trees where Caledonian pine forests once stood. For more images of Scotland, follow me @jimrichardsonng.  #scotland #scottishhighlands  #heather #highlands #rewilding #Cairngorms

Photo by Prasenjeet Yadav @prasen.yadav | A villager in northern India's Spiti Valley brings his yak home from open pasture. The yak is a domesticated bovid with a long, furry coat that helps it live in the high and cold mountains of Asia. For a major part of the year, they are free-ranging, but just after winter they‚Äôre secured and brought back to the villages to support farming. As summer approaches, they shed their downy undercoats, which are combed out by locals and processed into a soft fiber resembling cashmere. This animal holds a special place in local communities and plays a crucial role in helping inhabitants survive in harsh conditions. Yaks are well adapted to high altitudes, with slightly larger hearts and lungs than cattle found at lower altitudes, as well as a greater capacity for transporting oxygen through their blood (a typical high-altitude adaptation). Follow me @prasen.yadav for more photos from India and Central Asia.

Photo by @francescolastrucci | In the heart of the dense forests of Cambodia‚Äôs Cardamom Mountains, the wildlife release station in Koh Kong hosts this beautiful wreathed hornbill, fully recovered and ready to be released back into the wild. The Cardamoms were once a stronghold for Khmer Rouge fighters, a no-man's-land from which, until recently, outsiders were banned. Decades of isolation and inaccessibility kept this environment and its biodiversity nearly untouched, until loggers and poachers found their way into its forests. The ecosystem rapidly came to a critical point, but recently a few environmental organizations and a handful of locals have put their efforts together to save one of the longest remaining stretches of untouched rainforest in Southeast Asia and its biodiversity. The most evident of the area‚Äôs conservation successes stands in Chi Phat, a community of 500 families at the center of the Cardamoms, where the men who once fought the rebels now welcome and host intrepid travelers, while former poachers and loggers have now switched sides to work with the rangers. Soeun, the man who found and healed the injured hornbill, assures me that there is still hope for this lush rainforest to be preserved.   Follow me @francescolastrucci for more places, daily life, and stories from around the world. #cambodia #environment #rainforest #conservation

Photos by Jeff Mauritzen @jeffmauritzen | Words by @jkglobaltext.   Under the fluid light of Atlantic skies, the islands off Ireland‚Äôs west coast are rugged, romantic realms caught between myth and reality. Small wonder these windswept outposts have drawn filmmakers for decades. The Banshees of Inisherin is the latest film to tap the atmospheric magic of Ireland‚Äôs western shores. The setting for Martin McDonagh‚Äôs fable is a fictional Atlantic island whose name translates as ‚Äúthe island of Ireland.‚Äù McDonagh‚Äôs movie was shot on the Aran Islands, off Galway, and on Achill Island, further north. For visitors, both locations are well worth the effort to reach their remote shores.   Seen from above, Aran appears as a latticework of stone walls thrown over rough fields like a crocheted cloak. No trees grow on these barren limestone shards stretching out into the Atlantic. These three ‚Äústepping stones to America‚Äù hold only shallow fields, fertilized over time with seaweed. Step off the boat and you‚Äôll hike around the same patchwork of stonewall-lined fields as the characters in Banshees. Wherever you roam, the wondrous western light prevails.   Cinematographer Cian de Buitl√©ar, whose company supplied lighting equipment for Banshees, also filmed Islandman (2003) around Aran. ‚ÄúOn the Atlantic Irish seaboard the weather changes so fast‚Äîit‚Äôs said you might see four seasons in a day here,‚Äù he observes. What is truly unique about the west, says the filmmaker, is its crisper, brighter quality of light than elsewhere. ‚ÄúThis is because the Atlantic winds allow no build-up of heat haze,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúSo even filming on Aran, sometimes  you have crystal clear views 70 miles south to Kerry.‚Äù To read more stories from Ireland on this St. Patrick‚Äôs Day, explore the new National Geographic book "Always Ireland‚Äù by Jack Kavanagh. #StPatricksDay

Photo by @acacia.johnson | A brown bear nurses her cubs in Alaska‚Äôs McNeil River State Game Sanctuary, where more brown bears gather to fish each summer than has been observed anywhere else on Earth. Photo by @nicholesobecki | Musicians like Faisal Al Saari are expanding on ancient traditions, weaving together Emirati oud music and a vast sampling of global sounds. Passed down through generations, the oud remains at the core of modern Arabic music. Al Saari, an Emirati musician and composer, has spent three decades mastering these age-old sounds. Photo by @nicholesobecki | The soft pinks and purples of early dawn color the gray mangroves of Jubail Mangrove Park, a haven for species native to Abu Dhabi and birds migrating between Africa and Eurasia. Even beyond wildlife, the value of this ecosystem is immense. Coastal forests like this one function as blue carbon sinks, storing up to 10 times more carbon than their green counterparts on land (and holding it in the soil and sediment even after a tree dies). Not far away, the morning hustle was gaining pace amid towering skyscrapers, but here the lesson was one of quiet resiliency. As our world prepares for rising temperatures and seas, scientists hope that the adaptability of these mangroves‚Äîalready facing abnormally high salt levels in their shallow tidal waterways, as well as wild temperature swings‚Äîwill emerge in more ecosystems elsewhere in the world. | Abu Dhabi welcomes you. In the morning flocks of penguins gather on the beach before heading out to sea to feed. Kings aren‚Äôt picky eaters exactly, but they‚Äôre very specific about what they hunt and catch. They eat small, schooling fish like lanternfish (myctophids) year-round, especially during breeding season. When the weather grows colder they eat more icefish and cephalopods‚Äîmollusks, octopus, and squid‚Äîto supplement their winter diet. Giraffes, unfortunately, are in trouble. Giraffe populations have dropped in the past three decades, plummeting from approximately 155,000 in the late 1980s to about 110,000 in 2020. Reticulated giraffes number fewer than 16,000. The decline is thought to be caused by habitat loss and fragmentation and some poaching. Photos by @andrea_frazzetta | The Appian Way is among National Geographic Travel‚Äôs 2023 Best of the World destinations, highlighted as one of the best trips for immersing yourself in history and heritage.   The Appia is the most famous Roman road still in existence. It was one of Europe‚Äôs first highway systems and inspired the phrase "All roads lead to Rome." But its legacy has been largely neglected and its stones buried under millennia of history. Photo by @DaisyGilardini | Prion Island, in South Georgia‚Äôs Bay of Isles, is one of the main breeding sites for wandering albatrosses and is specially protected as a result. Wandering albatrosses are one of the world‚Äôs largest birds, with a wingspan of up to 3.5 meters (almost 12 feet). They are listed as vulnerable on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Major threats include longline fishing, bycatch fisheries, and climate change.   Wandering albatrosses are monogamous and breed every second year. The chick is fledged after roughly 10 months. It‚Äôs impressive to witness young albatrosses test their wings before flying for the first time. Photo by @daisygilardini | I am totally in love with the Svalbard reindeer. How could you not be, when it has such a cute muzzle? These reindeer are endemic to Svalbard and have adapted well to survive the harsh environment. Because they are sedentary, their energy demands are low, especially in winter, when food is scarce and they have to rely on their reserves of body fat. Their expected lifespan is around 10 years. One cause of death is starvation due to worn-out teeth from grazing on sparse vegetation mixed with gravel. Photo by @michaelgeorge // In Puerto Rico, El Yunque National Forest is filled with stunning hikes. One of the most rewarding and accessible is the short journey up to Mount Britton Tower. I began the trek standing in the shadow of a dense forest of palms. The trail vacillates between the welcome shade of the cloud forest and open areas filled with island sun. Though the distance isn‚Äôt far, I found myself energized by the challenge of this mostly vertical walk. Any huffing and puffing is well worth it, as the tower provides a gasp-worthy 360-degree view. Constructed in the 1930s, the stone structure provides visitors with a view of both the Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea. I could see the rainforest blending slowly into the coastline, with various cities resting in the valleys. After taking it all in, I sauntered down the spiral staircase and back into the cool embrace of the trees below. // The beautiful island of Puerto Rico has more to offer beyond its beaches. In Aztec mythology, the bird represents the sun god Huitzilopochtli, conceived by his mother after she clutched a ball of hummingbird feathers that fell from the sky to her chest.   üì∏ @aitorlaraphoto | Alba Heredia, a dancer from Granada, Spain, performs at Tablao Flamenco la Carmela in Madrid. Photo by @paoloverzone | A polar bear walks across the frozen sea in East Greenland. Polar bears live and breed in the northernmost regions of eastern Greenland. When the sea ice disappears, polar bears have to move onto land, where there are fewer feeding opportunities. Follow @paoloverzone for more images and stories.

Video of Nat Geo filmmaker @bertiegregory by @danbeecham | To film underwater, you need good diving skills. Equally important is the trim of your camera‚Äôs underwater housing. It‚Äôs very hard to get steady shots with badly balanced housing. I use lots of little weights on the bottom and noncompressible foam on the top, so when I let go, the housing stays upright. When filming in open water like I am here, I also leave the housing slightly positively buoyant. This means that if, in an emergency, I dropped the housing, it would float slowly to the surface. Filmed for Epic Adventures, now streaming on @disneyplus. #EpicAdventures #EpicAdventuresWithBertieGregory

Photo by @daisygilardini | A polar bear swims in open water during a mild summer day in the Svalbard archipelago. Midway between Norway and the North Pole, Svalbard is one of the last real Arctic wildernesses. Polar bears are incredibly good swimmers. Their average speed is 10 kilometers per hour (six miles per hour). The longest swim ever recorded was that of a subadult female that swam 426 miles (686 kilometers) over a period of nine days. Bears try to avoid long-distance swims when they can, though, because of the amount of energy expended while swimming. Unfortunately, due to the warming climate and the consequent loss of sea ice, long swims are becoming more frequent. While adult bears are protected from the cold water by a thick layer of fat (up to 11 centimeters, or 4.3 inches, in most cases), younger, skinnier bears and older bears are often at risk of hypothermia, which leads to drowning. Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories. #polarbear #conservation #svalbard #arctic #climatechange
Photo by @michaelclarkphoto / A herd of Bison in Biscuit Basin near Old Faithful in Yellowstone National Park on a snowy winter day in Wyoming. #bison #wyoming #yellowstone

Photo by @MichaelGeorge | After a week on the Antarctic Peninsula with mostly gray skies, it cleared up on our final evening. As sunset light began to paint the landscape, we saw three emperor penguins standing in the distance‚Äîa rare sighting of the largest penguin species. They wandered in and out of the shadows, but I caught this one in perfect light. For more photos and writing from my travels, follow along @MichaelGeorge. #emperorpenguin #penguin #antarctica #weddellsea #natgeoexpeditions

Photo by @francescolastrucci | A pilgrim admires the splendor of the Golden Temple at twilight. Built in the middle of a rectangular pool of "amrit" (holy water), it is believed to have healing powers and also gives name to the city of Amritsar. Also known as Harmandir Sahib, the temple is the most sacred site in the world for Sikhs. The complex has four entrances oriented according to the four cardinal points to symbolize the belief of the Sikh in equality and to welcome all people regardless of religion or provenance into their holy place to experience one of the most tangibly spiritual places in India. As visitors walk in circles around the marble pavement that surrounds the sacred pool, enchanting music induces a constant yet delicate state of trance. Follow me @francescolastrucci for more places, daily life, and stories from around the world. #india #goldentemple #dailylife

Video by @andrea_frazzetta | The Appian Way is the most famous Roman road still in existence and, according to modern criteria, it‚Äôs the first road that was ever built. In its 380-mile (612-kilometer) span across the country, the road takes many forms: a forested dirt path, a town plaza, a busy east-west highway. It‚Äôs not always scenic or pleasant but can be an immersion into the side of southern Italy few tourists see.  To realize this project, I traveled and walked for seven weeks. At the end of my journey, I rediscovered my country as I never imagined I would. I was amazed by the beauty and outraged by the ugliness of the road‚Äôs current state of disrepair.  Protection is now under way, but without visitors, the Appia could be forgotten again. As Riccardo Carnovalini, one of the most prominent Italian hikers, told me when I met with him on the trail: ‚ÄúWalking is the most political act one can do to change the landscape.‚Äù  Follow me @andrea_frazzetta for more images from this project. #Italy #appianway #Roma #lastrada

Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Farmers play chinlone at night after a long day on the field in Pa Dan Kho village in Myanmar. Chinlone, also called caneball, is Myanmar's national sport. This ancient traditional game typically focuses more on teamwork than competition. It is played around a circle and consists of the players using their feet and legs to pass the ball, keeping it in the air. Hands are normally not allowed to touch the ball. Played for more than 1,500 years, chinlone is a tradition that is very much alive today. Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens. #myanmar #chinlone #caneball #sport

Photo by @francescolastrucci | It is difficult for Corleone, Sicily, to escape its stereotypes, but beyond its cinematic clich√©s is the real city of Corleone, rich in history, culture, faith, traditions, and friendly people. Called the city of a hundred churches, Corleone's historic center owes its splendor to its maze of alleys and the presence of precious and fascinating palaces and buildings of worship. Corleone's anti-Mafia documentation center houses some of the most important testimonies of the fight against the Mafia in Sicily. The surrounding wilderness offers breathtaking landscapes.  A few months ago, I had the pleasure to hike across the island of Sicily, Italy, starting from the North coast town of Palermo and following the paths to the South coast town of Agrigento. Long forgotten, this 9 days long walk was once part of the famous and over a thousand years old trans-european Via Francigena and it‚Äôs now a newly revived ancient pilgrimage route. Carrying the name of ‚ÄúMagna Via Francigena‚Äù it shows the traces that Greeks, Romans, Arabs and Aragonese left throughout history in this Sicilian crossroad. Follow me @francescolastrucci for more places, daily life, and stories around the world. #sicily #italy #dailylife #documentaryphotography

Photo and video by @andrea_frazzetta | A group called La Taricata performs an Italian folk dance in Mesagne, the penultimate city along the Appian Way. The dance is known as ‚Äúpizzica,‚Äù a typical Apulian dance from Salento that was said to heal women from the venom of a tarantula, a spider that held great power in southern Italian folklore. The Appia has been a feature in daily life for Italians since its construction in 312 B.C. In fact, Italians still refer to the route with reverence as Regina Viarum‚Äîthe Queen of Roads. To see more photos from my travels, follow me @andrea_frazzetta. #Italy #appianway #dance #pizzica

Photo by @kahliaprilphoto // The first light of day touches the Ten Peaks on a crisp winter morning at Moraine Lake in Banff National Park. A familiar sight for many in the summer months, this magical lake takes on a completely different look as it transitions into winter. With road access closed, getting to the lake becomes a 26-kilometer (16-mile) journey on foot. Timing is everything to photograph and experience the changing light while the lake is completely frozen but not yet covered with snow. Setting off in the dark in the early hours with a headlamp, I took a chance on this cold, clear morning, and everything came together. // When you dare to explore the unfamiliar, you feel more alive. Choose adventure and discover the thrill of getting outside this winter with @5gum.

Photo by @chrisburkard | Few landscapes feel as vast as Monument Valley, with its towers casting ancient shadows over you. The scale here is so large, yet tiny organisms made up of algae and fungi live in the ground and create cryptobiotic soil, giving uncommon value to an already spectacular land.

Photo by @babaktafreshi // At 69¬∫N latitude, well inside the Arctic Circle, this fjord near Troms√∏, Norway, is an incredible spot from which to view the northern lights. When I hiked down to the shore on this crystal clear March night, the aurora was completely absent, but after a few hours of patience in the cold, this impressive, earlike swirl suddenly formed near midnight. My heart was beating like a drum. It was hard to take my eyes off of the scene and concentrate on the camera. Thanks to the moonlight, the five-second exposure was long enough to reveal the landscape but not so long that it diffused the fast-moving aurora pattern. The lights occur when electrically charged particles interact with gases in the upper atmosphere. They are drawn by Earth's magnetic field to the polar regions. // When you dare to explore the unfamiliar, you feel more alive. Choose adventure and discover the thrill of getting outside this winter with @5gum.

Photo by @MichaelGeorge | The harried modern world slips away as soon as you cross over to the breathtaking coastline of St. Abb's Head National Nature Reserve. I walked to an outlook, with the sea many feet below, and imagined these hillsides in spring, when it is said they are covered in an assortment of colorful native wildflowers. While hiking along the soaring heights of the bluffs, you might even spot a dolphin or a whale. Just be sure to bring your binoculars! Photo by @MichaelGeorge | The snowy sheathbill is the only land bird that‚Äôs native to Antarctica. They were also the only birds to take up temporary residence on our ship deck. Photo by @amivitale | Meet my llama friends. They're Montana locals who love having their picture taken. Photographing curious and affectionate llamas is like photographing people. The more time you spend with them, the more open they become. And animals, just like people, need to accept you before you can make great images of them. One secret is to never look at them directly. Animals often perceive eye contact as aggression, so if you cover one eye with your hand or your camera, they feel less threatened.   Llama-trekking is one of the many activities available in remote parts of Montana. Llamas have padded feet and can eat a wide variety of vegetation. Their impact is similar to that of deer. They are also alert and sure-footed, making them ideal and helpful companions for toting gear to Swan Lake, an area outside of Glacier National Park (@glaciernps).  Follow @amivitale for more stories about our connections to the natural world. #montana #llamas #trekking #camping #wilderness

Photo by @MichaelGeorge | Bowhill is a meticulously preserved 18th-century historic house in the heart of the Scottish Borders. A pedestrian path takes you through an oversized iron gate, acting as a preamble to the grandeur of the house itself. The property is so atmospheric, my mind conjured a classical soundtrack in time with my steps. When I entered the Victorian kitchen, restored in the 1970s, I was astounded by the size of the hearth and the soft color palette of the all-copper cookware. Bowhill facilitates a step into the past, and now managed by the Buccleuch Living Heritage Trust, the stunningly preserved house stands as a monument to conserving the Scottish countryside for future generations to enjoy. For more photos and writing from my travels, follow along @MichaelGeorge. #scotland #visitscotland #bowhill #scottishborders

Photo by @irina_sigl_photography | Congratulations to Irina Sigl on becoming the September 2022 @natgeoyourshot Photographer of the Month! Each month, we select a Your Shot Photographer who produced stunning work and fostered a sense of community.   The dragon is the symbol of Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia. Photos by @kiliiiyuyan // The Pacific Northwest is known for being wet, but up on Mount Baker, all that precipitation comes down as snow instead. In fact, Mount Baker holds the record for the most snowfall over a single winter season. Over time, that snow packs down into glacial ice. On our Mount Baker adventure, chef Melissa King and I took my handcrafted, traditional kayaks to Upper Bagley Lake and trekked about in the snow to forage for berries and other flavors of the alpine tundra. Mount Baker has many different ecosystems from bottom to top, including lush forests and alpine meadows filled with wildflowers. It‚Äôs a terrific journey to follow the Nooksack River all the way up to the snow, where it all starts. The mountain has several names in the Salish family of languages. It‚Äôs known as Kwelsh√°n by the Lummi and Nooksack peoples, who share its lands and hold deep relationships with the mountain. // The #MazdaCX50 is purpose-built to connect you with nature. After all, it‚Äôs on unpaved dirt and gravel paths where our sense of wonder comes alive. The first-ever Mazda CX-50. We‚Äôre more human in nature.

Photo by Michael Yamashita @yamashitaphoto | ‚ÄúBullet Train,‚Äù Brad Pitt‚Äôs latest action comedy film, takes place on Japan‚Äôs Tokaido Shinkansen, the busiest high-speed train line in the world. Operating between Tokyo and Osaka, this was the first bullet train line in Japan, opened in 1964, just in time for the Tokyo Olympics. Before the Shinkansen, a conventional train traveling between Tokyo and Osaka took six hours and 30 minutes to complete the trip. Now the latest N700 bullet trains, with maximum speeds up to 300 km per hour (180 miles per hour), can complete the trip in as little as two hours and 25 minutes. Video by @bertiegregory | I am often asked if wildlife filmmakers are running out of new animals and behaviors to film. Wildlife is in trouble all around the world, so you might think the answer is yes. If you venture out far from land and into the big blue, you reach the high seas, ungoverned and remote, where there are crimes against nature being committed out of sight and out of mind. Even so, if you search hard enough, there are still some unbelievable wildlife spectacles to be seen here. Filmed for my new show #EpicAdventuresWithBertieGregory on @disneyplus.

Video by @DaisyGilardini | The end of the life of a beautifully carved iceberg in Antarctica. The incredible life cycle of an iceberg starts thousands of years before it even reaches the sea. Snow and ice form glaciers on land. Over centuries of compression and slow movement, these glaciers expand toward the open sea. Once an iceberg calves from the mother glacier, it will float on ocean currents, at the mercy of some of the most inclement weather conditions on the planet. Snow, rain, wind, violent storms, and huge waves sculpt and carve its surface into amazing shapes and forms. The iceberg will flip upside down numerous times before disappearing into the depths of the ocean, not to die but to start its cycle all over again through evaporation. Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories. #Antarctica #ice #iceberg #conservation #climatechange

Photo by @daisygilardini | Harp seals in the Gulf of Saint Lawrence in Qu√©bec, Canada, give birth to their pups on the pack ice in February and March each year. They are yellowish in color at birth but turn a pure white after a couple of days, hence the label whitecoats. Poor ice conditions over the past few years have deeply affected the pups‚Äô mortality rates. Scientists say that while a single year of bad ice won‚Äôt affect the population unduly, poor ice patterns over a period of time could have a dramatic and worrying effect on the future of the species. Photo by @andrea_frazzetta | Rome‚Äôs third-century Arch of Drusus marks the informal start of a planned 360-mile (580-kilometer) walking route along the Appian Way. Although it may not seem like it, this scene is in the heart of Rome, a few hundred meters from the Baths of Caracalla.  The Appian Way is the most famous Roman road still in existence. It was one of Europe‚Äôs first highway systems and inspired the phrase "All roads lead to Rome."  But its legacy has been largely neglected, and its stones buried under millennia of history. Now a government project is under way to transform the Appia into a pilgrimage crossing from Rome to the sea on the heel of Italy‚Äôs boot, to bring thousands of visitors strolling across the wide, flat basalt stones.  To see more photos from my travels, follow me @andrea_frazzetta. #Italy #appianway #Roma

Photos by @MichaelGeorge | I could feel my legs burning as I cycled up to the grand overlook of Scott's View. This was one of Sir Walter Scott's favorite places to visit and sit for reflection. I welcomed the well-placed bench to catch my breath and take in the sweeping landscape, featuring Eildon Hill, an impressive formation made up of volcanic rock. Visitors can walk, cycle, or drive to this point to see the many geological features of the area. In late summer, you might even find a selection of fresh blackberries ready to be picked from the bushes at the top.   As I ambled along the River Tweed, a looming structure began to take shape in the distance. The Leaderfoot Viaduct, seen in the second image, is an iconic structure not far from the town of Melrose. The viaduct stands around 126 feet (38 meters) above the water and, because of its scenic placement, is a popular stop for travelers on the Four Abbeys Cycle Route. There are walking paths all around that allow visitors to take in the architecture from various angles. Though it is no longer in use, the viaduct was operated as part of the Berwickshire Railway from 1865 to 1948. On this clear day, I could easily imagine a steam train humming along the horizon. For more photos and writing from my travels, follow along @MichaelGeorge. #scotland #visitscotland #scottsview #leaderfootviaduct #cycling

In this very area, the well-known revolt of Spartacus broke out in 73 B.C.   One of the most significant findings from the Appian Way thus far is a bust known as the Philosopher‚Äôs Head.
