Photo by @MichaelGeorge | The owner of the Outdoor Centre in Loch Insh, Scotland, has a particularly unique connection to the country‚Äôs waterways. Here is an excerpt from my article on this region: ‚ÄúOne afternoon I met with the organizers of the Storylands Sessions, Merryn Glover and Hamish Napier, a local writer and a musician (seen in the second image of this carousel). These sessions promote the music and stories of the region, unearthing the many narratives that weave through the local community. As Merryn explains, it is drawing from the ancient tradition of ‚Äòc√®ilidh,‚Äô a Gaelic word for a gathering in people‚Äôs homes where bards, musicians, and storytellers once met to share poetry and songs. At one of their recent events, Duncan Freshwater told the story of his father‚Äôs legal battle for the right to navigate the River Spey. The case went all the way to the House of Lords in London, where he won when a 1782 case was cited that had established a Public Right of Navigation on the Spey, a victory that goes hand-in-hand with Scotland‚Äôs ‚Äòright to responsible access.‚Äô This ruling helped create the country‚Äôs cherished reputation for allowing adventurers to wild camp almost anywhere, as long as they travel responsibly, by treading lightly and leaving the land as they found it. Freshwater, a last name so fitting it feels like a wink, is one of the directors of the Loch Insh Outdoor Centre along with his two brothers.‚Äù For more photos and writing from my travels, follow along @MichaelGeorge. #scotland #badenoch #lochinsh #visitscotland #cairngorms

Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero | Sunset overlooking Thisa Wadi Temple in Bagan, one of my favorite places in the world to visit. Located about 600 kilometers (370 miles) from Yangon, Myanmar's largest city, this 11th-century kingdom once led by King Anawrahta boasted more than 4,000 temples. Although half of them have been destroyed because of earthquakes and man-made forces, more than 2,000 structures still survive today. Thisa Wadi Temple was commissioned by a queen in A.D. 1287.   I was supposed to go on a one-month trip to Myanmar in 2013. When I arrived, I immediately fell in love with the country and its people. I ended up staying for two and a half years. It is where I began my journey as a professional photographer.  Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see the world through my lens. #myanmar #bagan #buddhist #temple #pagoda

Photo by @MichaelGeorge | Walking before the Great Tapestry of Scotland, I realized I could spend a whole day here and still miss many of the intricate details. Located in Galashiels, the tapestry is a massive, community-focused artwork made up of 160 panels that illustrate the history of Scotland, with topics ranging from wars and battles to Dolly, the famously cloned sheep. Photo by @amivitale | A mother giraffe embraces her calf outside the small village of Doulouwal Peulh in Niger. In this small enclave 50 miles (80 kilometers) from the capital city of Niamey, people live side by side with the endangered West African giraffe in Niger's government defined Giraffe Zone. There are only about 600 West African giraffes left on the planet (up from a low of 49 in the wild, itself a conservation success).  In December 2018, the Giraffe Conservation Foundation, with the Niger government and other partners, endeavored to move eight of these highly threatened giraffes from the zone to Niger's Gadabedji Biosphere Reserve, from which they had been absent for more than 50 years. The translocation has been a huge success, and one of the giraffes has had a baby.  Learn more, including how to support those working to protect these creatures, by following @giraffe_conservation and @amivitale for more stories. #SaharaConservationFund #conservation #environmentalism #giraffes #niger

Photo by @hellokrisdavidson | A tree photographed through a car windshield during a thunderstorm on Sapelo Island, one of eight major barrier islands along the Georgia coast. Collectively, these barrier islands comprise an ephemeral landscape seemingly made of water, sand, and salt‚Äîa place shaped and governed by winds and tides. Sapelo Island is a stunningly beautiful and wild place, separated from the mainland by two sounds and nine-foot (three-meter) tides. There is no road to Sapelo‚Äîone must travel by air or water, and one must be invited. Today, most of the island belongs to Georgia and is managed by the state‚Äôs Department of Natural Resources. About a third of the island is a protected reserve where scientists study wildlife, including eagles, falcons, sea turtles, and other marsh creatures. Nestled inland is Hog Hammock, a seawater Gullah Geechee community. The few roads stretching across Sapelo are unpaved and without street signs or streetlights. Humanity‚Äôs presence feels fleeting here, as though nature might wash it away with a rainstorm. #Sapeloisland #gullahgeechee #Georgia

Video by @bertiegregory | Good preparation is critical to having a comfortable dive in Antarctica (comfort is relative!). Here, you can see Dan Beecham checking the seal on my full-face presenter mask. Any leaks would give me brain freeze and interfere with the inbuilt microphone. Toward the middle of this video you can also see me empty my wetsuit glove. About five minutes before getting in the water, we fill our gloves with hot water to get the neoprene nice and warm. It‚Äôs really important to empty that water out before putting the gloves on. If you don‚Äôt, that little pocket of water gets cold during the dive and makes your fingers very, very chilly. If anyone is wondering why we‚Äôre in wetsuits and not drysuits in the -1¬∫C/30¬∫F water, we were filming leopard seals, and wetsuits allow you to be much speedier in and out the water. Filming for my new show #EpicAdventuresWithBertieGregory, now streaming on @disneyplus.

Combined with VR, space travel is within reach, too. Image 1: Artist Ryoji Ikeda‚Äôs LED light show of abstracted futuristic renderings reflected on a mirrored floor in a black room. Image 2: The Infinite, a NASA-inspired VR experience of a 3D model of the International Space Station. Image 3: Situated in West Texas, the McDonald Observatory is remote and blissfully free of light pollution. As one of the darkest places on Earth on a moonless night, it‚Äôs a perfect place to take in the night sky. #nightsky #timetravel #space

Photos of @natgeo filmmaker @bertiegregory by Will West | Our expedition to Antarctica for ‚ÄúEpic Adventures‚Äù was, without a doubt, the hardest shoot I‚Äôve ever done. Although the crossing from South America to Antarctica is normally rough, once we arrive we tend to film in sheltered bays and channels. But the wildlife spectacle we were searching for this time happens out in the open ocean, away from shelter. Another issue was that wildlife gatherings are thought to be biggest at the end of the Antarctic summer. As summer turns to autumn, the amount of daylight shortens and the weather gets bad. We ended up having just six good filming days on our six-week expedition. When not filming, we spent most of our time clinging to our anchorage at the infamous Elephant Island. Here, I‚Äôm attempting to talk to the camera in a 70-mph (112-kph) gale. Filming for #EpicAdventuresWithBertieGregory, my new show now streaming on @disneyplus.

Some use a technology that helps trigger cameras each time a bolt is detected, while some, like myself, hold the camera and try to predict, firing off the shutter multiple times. One of many highlights during the recent season of storm chasing in the American Midwest.

Photo by Luj√°n Agusti @lujanag | Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. Veky hugs a small foal during hygiene tasks performed on the herd. Every year, near summer, all the farm animals receive health care. Photo by @amivitale | A West African giraffe from Niger's Giraffe Zone, a government-defined region where giraffes and humans coexist, rests inside a boma before being translocated. There are only about 600 West African giraffes left on the planet (up from a low of 49 in the wild, itself a conservation success). In December 2018, the Giraffe Conservation Foundation, with the Niger government and other partners, moved eight of these highly threatened giraffes from the Giraffe Zone to Niger's Gadabedji Biosphere Reserve, from which they've been absent for more than 50 years. This is a hopeful story for an animal whose rapidly shrinking numbers are significant cause for concern. Photo by Luj√°n Agusti @lujanag | Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. "El Conde," a field-worker, poses for a portrait during sunset on Isla Grande de Tierra del Fuego after a day's work. Fieldwork in the southern territory is often marked by weather conditions. During the summer, the days are long (17 hours of daylight) and not so cold, which enables people to carry out most of the annual tasks. With the arrival of winter, the days are short (barely seven hours of daylight), and the inclement weather means staying indoors. In those moments, it is important to be stocked with food and a good amount of dry firewood. I documented the life and work of @baqueanostdf, a tourism project carried out by a family of old settlers in southern Patagonia. Follow me @lujanag to learn more about life and traditions in Tierra del Fuego.

Photo by @daisygilardini | I am usually away from home in October and November for the early season in Antarctica, but not in 2021. Having to reschedule around COVID-19 travel restrictions, I stayed closer to home and returned to Churchill, Manitoba, for the polar bear migration. Every year around this time, bears gather around the edge of the Hudson Bay. They wait there for the ice to form, then head out onto the ice to hunt for seals, their primary food source. When I returned home in mid-November, the Hudson Bay was still open water, with no ice. The bears were all around, and I could photograph them sparring in the white spruce forests just outside town. It‚Äôs quite unusual to see them among big trees. Historic data of the western Hudson Bay subpopulation of polar bears shows the bears are spending more time on land, because the ice is forming later in the season and melting earlier the following spring. The average number of days the bears spend on land has grown steadily over the past 40 years, and the consequences can be dramatic. This particular subpopulation, the most studied in the world, has declined by 30 percent since the early 1980s. Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories. #churchill #manitoba #visitmanitoba #polarbears #conservation

Photo by Reuben Wu @itsreuben | Although Stanton Drew is the largest Neolithic timber monument in Britain, Woodhenge is a more widely known example.   Just two miles from Stonehenge, Woodhenge was discovered as concentric ovals of empty postholes in the ground that once held wooden posts up to 25 feet tall. Woodhenge is similar to Stonehenge in that it was likely built to align with the summer solstice sunrise. However, it is thought that very different forms of rituals took place at each monument.  Today the holes are marked by short concrete pillars‚Äî not the most photogenic of locations, but I imagine how impressive the original timber structure would have looked.  The final image was created with five layered exposures.   Read the full story at the link in bio and for more photos and stories on Stonehenge, follow me @itsreuben #stonehenge

Photo by @daisygilardini | Katmai National Park and Preserve in Alaska was established in 1918 to preserve the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes volcanic area. Nowadays it‚Äôs mostly visited for its abundance of brown bears. From spring to fall, Alaska‚Äôs coastal brown bears have access to different sources of food before retiring for the winter to their hibernation dens. During low tide they like to wander the mudflats in search of clams. It is also during low tide that they are more successful when fishing for salmon at river mouths. I was lying on my tummy to get a lower perspective when this bear passed by. I took advantage of the wet, exposed pebbles to create a very photogenic bokeh effect, shooting straight into the light and silhouetting the bear. Photo by @daisygilardini | I photographed this old iceberg while cruising at sunset along the Antarctic Peninsula. Icebergs form when ice calves from a glacier. Snow accumulates on a glacier and gets compressed over time by new precipitation. Hundreds or thousands of years of compression gradually eliminate the air bubbles from deeper layers. When sunlight hits the compressed ice, longer color wavelengths, like red and yellow, are absorbed, reflecting only the blue and green that are visible to our eyes. Follow me @daisygilardini for more images and behind-the-scenes stories. #Antarctica #iceberg #climatechange #polar  #landscapephotography

Photos by @francescolastrucci | A few months ago, I had the pleasure of hiking across the island of Sicily, starting from the northern coastal town of Palermo and following the paths to the southern coastal town of Agrigento. Photos by @andrea_frazzetta | The Appian Way has been a feature in daily life for Italians since its construction beginning in 312 B.C. It was one of Europe‚Äôs first highway systems and inspired the saying ‚ÄúAll roads lead to Rome.‚Äù After centuries of abandonment, a government project is underway to transform the Appia into a pilgrimage crossing from Rome to the sea on the heel of Italy‚Äôs boot. Photo by @andrea_frazzetta | At the end of an evening in the Appian Way Regional Park, during which I attended an outdoor screening of a neorealist movie, I found myself walking along the street until I came across a small trattoria that sets up a few tables right on the ancient Roman basalt. I timidly began to take pictures of the diners and then found myself dining and drinking wine with them on the 2,000-year-old stones. It got dark, and around midnight I took this portrait of Giovanni, who lives a few steps away. Suddenly, the scenes of the movie I had just watched were in front of me. The director Federico Fellini was one of the affectionate patrons of this historic trattoria, called Qui Nun Se More Mai‚Äî‚Äúhere we never die‚Äù‚Äînow run by brothers Armando and Erminio. The full story about the Appian Way is in the July issue of @natgeo. Follow me @andrea_frazzetta to know more. #Italy #appianway #Roma

Photo by @amivitale | Sheila Walsh rides her horse as the sun sets behind her at Matador Ranch in Montana. Matador‚Äôs grassbank program, a partnership between the Nature Conservancy and local ranchers, is an innovative way to encourage conservation. It has helped to keep native grassland intact, remove obstacles to pronghorn antelope migration, improve habitat for the greater sage-grouse, reduce the risk of sage-grouse colliding with fences, preserve prairie dog towns, and prevent the spread of noxious weeds.
